reviewText: So I got me a copy of "The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button" and I'll tell you what, I didn't expect what I got. It was an awesome movie in every sense of the word. If you love life then you should see this movie because this is life at it's best. A journey through a mans life that is running backwards in age was very interesting, the only part I thought was weird was when he was getting younger and eventually went back to being a baby. Other than that this was a great story about just living your life to the fullest and to just be happy no matter what life throws at you, If you liked "Forrest Gump" than you should like this movie. Cate Blancett did a very good job as Benjamin's love and I thought her to be more attractive than usual in this one. All around good acting and a great life and love story, highly recommend this for everyone to see. But on a side note, love life and live it to the fullest everyday because someday we all gotta go, why not make the best outta what we have? That's how this movie inspired me, to live my life to the fullest and to be happy with everything I have and not to take life for granted. I really hope some of you watch this movie and feel what I felt from it.

"The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" is a wonderfully staged fantasy based on F. Scott Fitzgerald's fantasy about a boy born old and aging younger instead of older. The story could obviously be off-putting and distracting, but everyone involved does such a magnificent job of telling this story that it is not hard to accept this as fact, and following the story as it shows Benjamin growing younger and falling in love with a young girl named Daisy.

Benjamin and Daisy's story and the balance of Benjamin's life impart so many valuable life lessons that it is hard to recount them all - the idea that life brings many hardships and the best we can do is doing the best we can with what we're given, making the most of every moment because life is fleeting and unpredictable, find the joy and happinessin life and hold on to it dearly, and many other lessons.

"Benjamin Button" gives Brad Pitt the chance to shine in the title role, and he makes the most of it. He is ably assisted by Cate Blanchett as Daisy, Taraji P. Henson as Benjamin's adoptive mother, Tilda Swinton as another love of Benjamin's, and many others. This film is marvelous and a hopeful fable for all of us.

Okay, so call me old fashioned, call me cliche, call me vapid, but I really, really love The Curious Case of Benjamin Button. Damn all those who say its Forrest Gump 2.0, damn those who say its too long, damn everyone who thinks its overly shamltzy, I think its a great film and one of the best fantasy films since LOTR.

The story tells of Benjamin Button, who by some weird twist of fate, was born with the body of an old man and as he gets older, he ages backwards. We are then taken on his life and all his life adventures, from growing up in an old folks home with his adoptive mother Queenie, spending his early adult life as a sea boater, and coming back to America for his childhood friend and love interest Daisy.

I think I speak for everyone that the film is gorgeously made, considering it did pick up three Oscars for many of its technical aspects, the set pieces evoking the time period, the cinematography rich, art direction meticulous, and of course, those special effects, those awesome special effects that transform the handsome Brad Pitt from an old man to a spiting image of Brad the first time we saw him in Thelma & Louise.

Now unlike many, I actually thought Button was that film that didn't feel long. At nearly three hours, you would expect this to be true but for me, the film really just glided along and the pacing was so effortless, it was like I was transported to another world, something I haven't experienced since, ironically, LOTR.

This mostly has to do with Fincher, known for his dark, sinster films like Seven and Zodiac. Leaving behind all that for a more lighter fair, you can still detect his touches in the film. After all, this film is essentally about life and death, Benjamin slowly aging backwards, his life in reverse, watching as the world changes while he seems to be going further and further into the past, all leading towards that time when he will eventually die. And I for one think Fincher keeps things from getting to shmaltzy, giving the film a heart but not such a ooey, gooey center that feels too sweet.

Each actor also brings life to their performance. Brad Pitt is able to act through all that make up and effects to deliver a very sturdy and calm performance, something I think that many would have think was way to subtle in order to pull of the effects, but I think it works, he dosen't try too hard to make it a good performance, he just does. Taraji P. Henson was a very nice surprise as Benjamin's adoptive mom Queenie, giving both wit, charm, and personality, but once again, keeping it from becoming too stereotyped or cliche. And as always, Cate Blanchett is as a great as ever (still very shocked she was ignored through out the awards season).

Honestly, I think Benjamin Button is one of those films that you either love it or hate it. For me, I fall into the love it catagory, and you know what? I'm proud off it. Whether or not you like Brad Pitt, or don't life fantasy films, or just turned off by some of the lukewarm reviews, give Button a chance. Maybe you'll hate it, maybe you'll be indifferent, but if your like me, you'll find a very rich, thoughtfull, and heart tugging film that is that true Hollywood experience.

Walking into `The Curious Case of Benjamin Button' I was excited.  I had read the short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald and so my appetite was wet.  Not only that, but the film had been raved by many as the best of the year; it was winning all sorts of awards and looked prime for the Best Picture Oscar.  Aside from that, I am a huge fan of Cate Blanchett and Brad Pitt and so I think it is safe to say that `The Curious Case of Benjamin Button' looked like it just may be the perfect movie to me.

In a world filled with the same ol' same it is always refreshing to see a film with such an original prose.

Truth be told, when walking into a film so widely hyped and anticipated one is often setting themselves up for disappointment, which is sad because one is not able to separate hype from the actual experience long enough to gather their own individual (un-manipulated) feelings on the matter.  That is precisely why I loathe writing a review so soon after seeing a film, without fully processing it as a whole, and it is precisely why I wait until a films DVD release to give my final collected thoughts.

Sadly, with `Benjamin', I couldn't wait.

Walking out of `The Curious Case of Benjamin Button' I felt a little cold.  Many critical reviews of the film labeled that the films solitary weakness; that it left you emotional detached.  It was less that and more emotionally robbed I think.  I wanted to feel attachment and I wanted to feel moved, but I didn't.  There are moments (especially with regard to Benjamin's decisions about `family') that play with the heart strings and can bring tears, but the films delivery is at such a stagnant pace that it makes it difficult to find an emotional foundation.  Brad Pitt's performance, while solid, is at times almost lifeless and this can add to the lack of emotional chemistry with the audience.  He tells us how one should be feeling (in a very slick and enjoyable voice over) but we can never truly grasp what Benjamin is feeling because he is so closed off.

He is merely an observer, letting us see the journey of his life but never truly letting us experience it with him.  Someone mentioned the word `canvas', that Benjamin was a blank canvas on which those around him painted the story of their lives.  That sounds about right, for it is the people around Benjamin that engage us the most.

Having read the short story I of course have my qualms with the films adaptation, minor as they may be.  Let me first say that the film is drastically different from the story, which is shocking since the short story was expertly crafted.  Having Benjamin grow up in a nursing home under the care of a foster mother was an inspired departure from the story, and it gave way to some nice character development on the part of Benjamin, Daisy and of course his foster mother Queenie.  I am not upset about this alteration one bit.  In fact, I am delighted with it.  My main complaint with the films departure from printed page comes in the films end, (and subsequently the films `modern day' beginnings) and the way that Benjamin's `family' is handled.

I'll scream SPOILERS...just so you are aware.

In the story the real meat of Fitzgerald's moral comes from the way Benjamin is regarded by his loved ones once he becomes `younger' than they are.  Whether it is Daisy's disgust with her younger husband merely because he is a constant reminder of her age or his children's disgust with their father beings that they must now take care of him, the story's major wind is found in its ending.  I won't say how this film ends, but let's just say that the choice made my Button in regards to his family, while emotional upon impact, is much less effective or enlightening as Fitzgerald's original prose.

On another note in regards to the ending, I felt as if it was trying to make up for the films overall stiffness by giving us that sentimental monologue that just didn't fit ("some people dance").

The films biggest conundrum is David Fincher, the films director.  I am a huge fan of his work and was very excited to see him garnering the respect and admiration he has so long deserved, but this is not the film for which he should have received it.  He may deliver the film to us almost like a poet, but his poem is almost devoid of real substance.  It is very fluid and very `epic' yet it still feels very small.  I told a friend that this was a small story given epic treatment yet it still comes off like a small film.  This is a blessing and a malediction, for the film has the intimate qualities of an independent film with the visual grandeur of an epic Hollywood escapade.  That's the blessing.  The malediction comes from the fact that, while it boasts the visual splendor (an area in which it excels) it never takes full advantage of the intimacy it possesses.  There are so many quiet moments within `Button' that feel lost.  There is a delicate side story containing the marvelous Tilda Swinton that is probably the most effective and `complete' portion of the film, and it made me sad because the rest of the film lacked the sharpness that that sequence of events contained.  When you watch the film you may not immediately see what I'm pointing out (although if you read this before you watch the film then you might see it front and center) so I can't fault it too much.  Fincher does some phenomenal work here visually, but emotionally he drops the ball.

It is beautiful to look at, each frame floating by like clouds.  Nothing is choppy; nothing is rigid; every frame is smooth and delicate and comforting.

As far as the acting is concerned, it is solid but never truly noteworthy.  Brad Pitt is a very capable actor, but like I've already mentioned, his delivery of Benjamin is more of an observer, not a participant.  Cate Blanchett is stunning in scenes, downright captivating at times, but goes cold towards the films end, where sentiment would have been most effective, and this put me off a bit.  Tilda Swinton and Taraji P. Henson give the most inspired performances here.  Swinton makes the most of her small screen time to deliver a truly touching performance, and Henson uses her charm and fiery deliver to add a glimmer of life to her scenes that are captivating and utterly essential.  I also enjoyed Jason Flemyng's portrayal of Benjamin's father Thomas, and I was so excited that the screenwriters still worked in Benjamin's relationship with his father even though they changed his living arrangements.

As many have already noted about this film though, it is not an actor's showcase.  This is a technical achievement if nothing else, and technically it is splendid.  Fincher has crafted what may very well be his most technically proficient film.  It's just a shame that that proficiency was not carried on into the heart of the film.  Fincher failed to balance out the two ends of his film and thus delivered to us a beautifully shot yet emotionally vapid film.

I did like this movie, and maybe over time I will see it differently.  I just don't love it like I thought I would have.  It could have been improved upon had Pitt delivered a little more life to Benjamin.  It also would have been preferable to have some of the films center trimmed to allow more depth given to the films end, which is really the most important part of the story.  I cannot knock this movie entirely (and I'm sorry if it looks like I'm ripping it to shreds in parts of this review) because it is entertaining and enjoyable and very beautifully directed; but I must call it out for its missteps and at least be true to my own opinions.  I'd watch it again, most definitely, but the film feels sorely like a missed opportunity.

I just want to close out by saying that while I wrote this review months ago, after my first viewing of the film, I have since revisited the film and reviewed my review and I agree with every word.

For all reviewers who bashed this movie, I say you just didn't "get it".  Sure, it's a fantasy so you have to take that as intended.  But there are some real messages here.  It should get you to thinking about how we look (and deal with) acceptance of one another, relationships, death, our parents, love and the many people we meet in life who help shape who we are.  Too many movies nowadays are over the top in action.  This is a quiet movie - so sit back, open your mind to the underlying tone and enjoy - it's one of the better movies out there!

What a ridiculous film. I can't believe how much aclaim it received. It was silly, stupid and pointless. This just goes to show you that in hollywood, looks are all that matter.....because that is what sells tickets at the box-office!

Let me get this right out there, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a well made film with great acting. It just doesn't have any solid point but following the old young man until he is a young old man. Like anyone's life shown in whole, there is no climax and only a few interesting revelations which show themselves too early before the film's end. In short, everything that is done in this film was done much better in Forrest Gump and with more humor. The CGI process of making people look old and young is a true revolution in technology. It is thanks to that and everyone's fine acting that this got 3 stars from me. Worth a rental but not a buy.

This movie is a masterpiece in both art and photography. The scene's and CGI are astounding integrated with a plot line that will let the movie breeze by. There are so many elements to this movie that you will find something to enjoy.

However it is long so keep that in mind when you put it in.

Oscar nomination or not, this is the most boring movie I've seen since MEET JOE BLACK. It's sad to see so much talent and effort gone to waste but what exactly is appealing about this story ? Why on earth would a little girl and a seemingly old man find themselves bonded to each other in the first place ? Why don't Guiness/Ripley or the media stop by when what you've got here is the ultimate freak story ?. The only fun I had throughout this movie was making a list of the similarities with Forrest Gump which run in the several dozens. The Katrina back-story could have been of interest but at the end, all they used it for is as an excuse to flood a room ! This movie has easily the best aging effects in history but you end up noticing you spend most of the time evaluating them instead of getting involved with the story which is the basic symptom that this movie fails.

The Curious Case of Benjamim Button is by no means a feel-good movie. In fact upon watching it, I felt depressed even the next day just thinking about it. People may confuse this for a love story but to me the film clearly symbolizes death. The love aspect is certainly present, though it is not the center of attention here.

Brad Pitt stars as Benjamin Button, a man who essentially ages backwards. When he is born, his own father attempts to drown him before a sudden change of heart has him leaving the swaddled and very whithered newborn upon the steps of an elderly home. There he is found by Queenie, played to motherly perfection by Taraji P. Henson. She sees past the deformity and oddity and loves him immediately.

Instead of dying, as a doctor predicted, Benjamin actually begins to age backwards. He appears as a very old man and slowly grows younger, but only in body. His mind seems to function as a typical human's mind. He learns, and dreams and experiences. This basically sets up the magnificent story and from then on, you are taken from country to country, from one decade, to another and it is just superb to witness.

The acting is fantastic all around. Brad Pitt does an outstanding job, portraying both the old Benjamin as well as his younger counterpart. Cate Blanchett as his childhood friend/love interest is also a joy to watch. She can do no wrong, she is simply stunning. For such a short part, Tilda Swinton surely makes the most of it. Her tale and part with Benjamin in Russia is just stunning. There is also the talented Julia Ormond, who has a bigger part to play in the tale than we may realise at first.

The most impressive aspect of the film is the flawless visual effects. Just flawless. You have never seen aging/deaging done like this. There is a scene, towards the end, with Benjamin and Daisy (Blanchett) that had my jaw dropping. It was like looking back in time. I can't describe how utterly impressed I was. The cinematography, the sad musical score, the costumes, just every little minute detail is just so impressive and authentic.

I have heard grumbles from people who compare it to Forrest Gump. What? How? There should not be any comparing the two films-or the two characters. Gump was a slow and mostly ignorant person who fell into unbelievable situations. Button clearly chooses his own paths, though it may not seem it, at the beginning. It irritates me how someone can make such a comparison.

This is a long film, nearly three hours, though with the plot and subject matter, it makes sense and really, it is such a beautiful film, you hardly notice the passing of time. Like I mentioned, it will leave you feeling blue but that does not diminish from the fact this is one of the better newer films out there now, and one that people will remember in the future.

I love this show.... This is the way life should be... Old first and then grow young.. By the time we can enjoy life we are too old to get around, have health issues.. This way we can learn while we are old and enjoy while we are young.

I found this movie uninteresting, but I kept watching (in 5 shifts), hoping something would improve this movie.  My wife dropped out after 15 minutes, finding it incomprehensible and boring.  Though the film fails to make clear what causes Benjamin to "age in reverse," my conjecture is that a large clock purposely built to run backward magically caused ONLY Benjamin's life to run backward.  That is one preposterous premise for a story!  There are more improbabilities along the way, such as his father's finding him after many years, in a big city.  Besides being unbelievable, the movie is replete with disgusting scenes of vomit, flies in a jar of honey, prostitution, and drunkenness.  The fact that the DVD stopped functioning in the middle actually rescued me from this disappointing experience.

This is a movie that many reviewers obviously deeply loved, but which others have found unsatisfying. As someone in the latter camp, let me take a stab at helping those who are trying to decide whether to watch this movie which camp they might fall in. Ultimately, I think the viewer's experience will depend on whether she or he most enjoys movies that focus on "being", or those that focus on "becoming". Viewers who derive great enjoyment from sharing a character's experiences of love, pleasure, pain, etc., will find much to like in this film. It's the work of top flight talent. However, viewers who get their pleasure from exploring the deeper effects of a character's unique experiences on his or her development as a person will probably find little to justify this film's nearly 3 hour viewing time. While it's a visually beautiful movie with much to like, in the end I felt it did little to exploit its very interesting premise of the main character's "reverse aging" (being born old and becoming progressively younger throughout his lifespan). The biggest problem for was the lack of central character development throughout the course of the film--the sense that Benjamin was doing more than experiencing and feeling, but was also learning and growing. He was like a travel suitcase that ended up with lots of stickers on the outside marking the interesting places he'd visited, but containing little of substance that he'd picked up along the way. Benjamin remained for me essentially an uninteresting person to whom interesting things happened, and that just wasn't enough for me to lift this into the category of great movies.

What a unique, extraordinary experience--not just for the main characters of this movie, but for the viewers themselves. The screenplay--with the feel of a theatrical play--is fantastic, and the acting by all is first rate. The atmosphere in the movie--aided by the music-- is like a protracted dream. The imagery is so vivid, my memory of its scenes so fresh, that I doubt I will be watching this movie again any time soon. I can just let it play anew in my head.

Even though it's a long movie, at the end I was wishing it would go on longer.  I wasn't ready to leave the characters.  If you're not sure about this movie go ahead, take the chance and watch it.  You won't regret it.

While I can see how this movie is meant to be touching and evocative, it has some serious issues, the worst of which is a tendency towards racial-historical denialism (idk if that is the most precise term). It's too firmly grounded in history/timelines for the people who produced it not to google some basics. Plus the movie's nearly 3 hrs long, and absolutely tedious--everyone knows the story going in; no need to establish every quirk. Some of the fake southern accents are terrible--at best they sound put-on, at worst they sound mocking. Oh and, since the majority of the movie is a flashback as read by the daughter to whom it's addressed, you kind of wonder at all the sex scenes (nobody wants to hear that about their parents.... Benjamin Button is a reserved guy so why the sudden indiscretion?)
(The movie's excessive length invites the mind to wander in an effort to avoid boredom, which leads one to consider all kinds of possibilities! Like "Daisy's" age at childbirth... hmmm. Or what the movie might be saying about the relative merits of absentee fatherhood. (Also, I think the fact that they used Brad Pitt's real baby is beyond creepy. But okay!))

This may be the worst movie I've ever seen because, in addition to crippling oversights, there is almost no upside. It's filled with cloying, unrealistic hopes and the flattest, doofy emotionalism. Oh, and, the dialogue: "[Daisy]: Sleep with me? [Benji]: Absolutely!" ----seriously?

As penance for my ranting criticism, I wanted to list some upsides:
1) Tilda Swinton is excellent (if the movie were a short film with just the Tilda Swinton parts, it'd be waaay more interesting)
2) Cate Blanchett looks very pretty with red hair
2) the first fifteen and last fifteen minutes of the film make a (remarkably!) moving parallel between Katrina and war (i think the movie started at the end of WWI --1918 seems right?) --especially if the parallel was to WWI, when the end of the war didn't bring peace, and "resolutions" paved the way for future problems. I stopped going to New Orleans in 2010 but huge parts still hadn't been cleaned up 5 years after the hurricane // ~2 years after this movie. Katrina relief was so profoundly insufficient, and the hurricane caused such devastation, that nola really was what I imagine a war zone would look like. So yes, while most of the movie made me gag, the clockmaker's speech hit oddly close to home.
But turning back time is impossible, and this entire line of thinking is counterfactual and unhelpful (unless nola saw a sudden influx of volunteers in 2008? doubtful). I want to give 2 stars for the feeble activism attempt but I just can't--this is really among the worst movies I've ever seen (and i saw troll2)

For a long while, this has been my favorite movie. The struggle of star-crossed lovers aging in the wrong direction and a man who has to deal with a life he must live all alone with. It is beautiful and heartbreaking in its honesty and never ceases to make me cry every single time I watch it. A movie that can solicit such a response from me despite how many times I watch it, is a masterpiece in my eyes. The cast is star studded with amazing actors who add color and substance to the whole world the film makers created. I smiled when they smiled and laughed when they laughed and feel genuinely invested in a man aging backward. I can feel his loneliness portrayed on screen and I believe that is attributed to not only Brad Pitts performance but also the script itself. I will come back to this movie again and again and expect it will keep making me cry every time I do.

This is actually a story within a story. Primarily, it tells an exceptional story of a man born with an unfortunate variation of "projeria", a disease that causes premature aging. In this fictitious variation, the baby is born with features and medical conditions consistent with a 70-year-old man but appears to be aging in reverse. The story is presented in the form of flash-backs from a hand-written diary that a young woman reads to her dying mother. As she reads more of it she begins to suspect that her mother's past is much more intertwined with this unfortunate (or fortunate) man than she first thought. By the time she finishes the diary she learns the truth about her mother's attempts to atone for her selfishness and some life-changing truths about herself. After his mother dies during child birth this unfortunate baby's father, repulsed by his appearance, abandons him on the steps of an "old folks home". A warm-hearted nurse takes pity on him and raises him as her own child right there in the nursing home. Because of his appearance, everyone assumes he is a frail old man. This gets him in trouble when he innocently yearns to play with others his age. He forms a bond with a visiting young girl that is renewed and strengthened later in life. The story follows his life through evermore thrilling and heart-warming adventures as he appears to get increasingly younger, periodically encountering his childhood friend. Folded into the pages of the dusty diary are postcards, photos, and notes that reveal more about how the daughter and her dying mother are connected to the man her mother has kept secret from her all these years... Stellar performances by Brad Pitt (Benjamin Button), Cate Blanchett (Daisy), and Taraji Henson (Queenie). Bravo!!!

I'll give it a 2nd star because it was well acted. Brad Pitt is playing a very unique character in that he is an old man with no life experience then a young man with decades of life experience. That's unique and opposite of normal character development. So that is a tough sell for an actor. An actor playing an old man has to carry himself with certain mannerisms that indicate he's tired and worn down while showing wisdom about the world around him. When playing a young man he has to show vibrancy and wonder about the world. This flips it all around. Pitt had to be young but wise and old but naive. As the viewer that's the opposite of everything you know about people so it messes with your mind. It would have been EASY for any actor to underdeliver that role and have the character be unbelievable. Pitt makes you believe the impossible character traits of Benjamin Button. So it's VERY well acted.

And it gets a 3rd star star because it was gorgeously filmed. I mean visually it's stunning. They color theme of the whole thing is dull Earth tones (browns, dull yellows, stuff like that) and somehow it still came across as visually vibrant. It's not easy to do that with a brown centered pallet. So MAJOR props to the cinematography.

But holy cow did the story ever just drag on forever. The story telegraphs it's own ending about 20 minutes into the film. So you almost immediately see where the story is going and what's going to happen. Then you're just waiting for it to get there.

And they tried to make the whole thing connected to Hurricane Katrina, but it didn't come across clearly.

I also wonder how come if he starts off as a baby sized old man, how come he doesn't turn into an old man sized baby?

I loved this. Beautifully done on almost every level, thoroughly imagined, and well-written. Wonderful performances from two great actors, as well as several excellent supporting ones. Even better, both the main characters are extraordinarily lovable, compelling, and an unusual joy to watch. Benjamin Button is an especially endearing creature, masterfully imagined and brought to life (minus two CGI glitches, but it sounds like most people didn't even notice this). I must say, I haven't seen a Hollywood character so endearing in a long time. Maybe because he starts out in such a doubly vulnerable, humble position -- which I do wish they'd unpacked just a little more, in terms of its effects on his psyche throughout life. But I think the point of that is that sometimes the things that may seem outwardly tragic or handicapping are really "miraculous" gifts that elevate us by making us better, wiser, more loving people. And as other reviewers have said better than me, this film really does have an extraordinary loving quality to it, a warmth and humanity so unfortunately rare for Hollywood these days. So glad I listened and decided to watch this! Cate Blanchett also shines as Daisy, a complex, charismatic character that wins us from the get-go. Both of them are perfectly imperfect. In fact, nearly every character has a certain perfectly imperfect humanity that's really hard to articulate but somehow touching in hindsight. I'm sure this is one I'll watch again to further unpack its subtle charms.

F Scott Fitzgerald's short story of a man aging in reverse has been beautifully ilongated and rewritten to epic proportions here. Brad Pitt is wonderful in the title role of a baby born old who gets younger every year. Cate Blanchett and others are outstanding here as well. If you have three hours to invest here it's well worth the time.

This movie is a obviously fashioned after Forrest Gump. The same monotone voice over and several of the characters repeated. The main difference is this movie is depressing. If you can overlook the absurd premise that the guy ages backwards, it still doesn't have anything positive to say. He is a coward who abandoned his wife only one year after the birth of their daughter. She is a promiscuous woman who desires the New York City lifestyle. They try to rewrite history and paint America as a amoral society from the end of the first world war while characterizing other nations as superior. Basically this is a left wing propaganda piece. Anyone who rated this high either didn't pay attention or is incapable of finding the true moral to the story.

Somehow I am blessed to only watch the best movies. This one is no exception. I resisted watching it for years, thinking the story line was impossibly corny. But the humanity and gentleness embodied by the characters is not to be missed. The vernacular for the era and geographic location is charming, as are the actors and actresses. I am happy to have spent an evening in the company of the unique Benjamin Button. Someday I hope all our clocks run backward.

"For what its worth: its never too late or, in my case, too early to be whoever you want to be. Theres no time limit, stop whenever you want. You can change or stay the same, there are no rules to this thing. We can make the best or the worst of it. I hope you make the best of it. And I hope you see things that startle you. Spoiler alert! Thomas Button arrives home to New Orleans after the cessation of WWI to the birth of his son, Benjamin (Brad Pitt), in 1919. The mother succumbs, and Thomas abandons the days-old infant on the doorstep of Miss Queenie. She is a black woman and head of household, who sees the baby as a miracle delivered from God to cherish. She adopts and raises the infant as though she gave birth to him, as if he was her own flesh and blood. During a Thanksgiving Day reunion in 1930, Benjamin becomes acquainted with 6-year-old Daisy (Cate Blanchett). In 1936, Benjamin, 17, leaves home and his tearful mother, Miss Queeie. He travels the world by sea for three years to Newfoundland, Baffin Bay, Glasgow, Liverpool, Narvik, and finally settles in India. After the Pearl Harbor attacks on December 7, 1941, Benjamin enlists in the Navy. In May of 1945, at 26, he returns home, looking more youthful than when he left. By some blazing genetic mutation, fantastical twist of nature, Benjamin was aging in reverse, getting younger (he was born in a decrepit, elderly state but rejuvenates physically, although he regresses from emotional maturity to immaturity as he ages). He intercedes into Daisy's life, once again, in the Spring of 1962, they elope, and have a daughter, Caroline. Though she did love him, he did not want to make a long-term commitment. After his daughter's first birthday, Benjamin tells Daisy that he is leaving her, because he doesn't want to burden her with raising two children, raising Caroline and himself, as he regresses. She was shocked by his departure. He rationalized he was doing it for Daisy, but selfishly relieved himself of any responsibly, so he could travel again as he did in his chronological youth. Fortunately for Daisy, she reunited with a former lover that became her caring husband and Caroline's surrogate father.

It is rather interesting to note that a creative story, written to be no more than a SHORT story, is here transformed into a rather long film. Nonetheless, it is interesting to watch, and is certainly well done in many aspects.

It is NOT depressing (as one viewer mentioned) but more of a thoughtful, pensive piece. It can tug on the heart strings, but it is not a truly depressing film, nor is it a tragedy. The main premise is to simply explore what life would be like if a child was one day born old and ugly, slowly grew young and beautiful, and then became innocent and completely without memory.

I do feel that something is missing, which I cannot place my finger on though. The acting is excellent, the aging (and UN-aging) process very well done, the lighting and sets great, and so on. I did find it rather obnoxious that he (Benjamin - and this is a spoiler alert) left his child, when he clearly appeared to have at least another twenty years where he could have raised her and been there, with enough time to eventually explain things to her. That was frustrating, and perhaps may have led to part of why the film seemed to miss something. Plus, the young love interest became cocky, arrogant, and annoying in her 20s, and was a real turn off in regards to enjoying the plot line.

I suppose it is really a little vignette of a story that did not realize it was supposed to be so, and therefore stretched itself out quite without need. It tried to present itself as the epic story of one mans life, when it was never intended to be. Yet it was an interesting watch, despite the fact that many scenes were not necessary to the entire story line. It missed something, but it had something all the same. I suppose that makes it curious, in more ways than one.

I see a lot of reviews of this movie being depressing or not having a point. As for depressing, well if a movie can give me an emotional reaction than it's succeeded in it's purpose. The fact a group of actors in makeup with spot lights on them and a film crew of hundreds gathered around them can create a product that makes you feel depressed or happy or afraid is impressive to me. And it does have a point.

At its core, this is a simple love story. 2 young people people meet, travel their separate paths in life, then meet again at middle age and fall in love. They eventually grow old together. The only twist is that the man in the relationship is aging backward physically. The point of the movie is to make the viewer wonder how they would react watching the love of their life growing younger before their eyes. Sure, going from a 50 year old to a 40 year old would be amazing, but how do you handle seeing them appear 10 years old? How about 5 years old? Knowing their life won't last much longer. It's the same life issues a wife deals with if her husband gets Alzheimer's, gets arthritis and can't walk, or has a heart attack and becomes paralyzed. But he's visually younger instead of wrinkled and aged. Blanchett's Daisy handles it with grace and patience. She has known Benjamin since she was a little girl, probably the only person left in his life who fully understands what is happening to him and has the love in her heart to bear with him as he grows into an infant. He forgets about her, he forgets his whole life, but she stays by him to the end. Forget gimmicky special effects or acadamy award this or that, just watch the movie closely and see how much Daisy loves Benjamin througout her life even with his bizarre affliction.

Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)  Based on the 1922 short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald, this drama-romance-fantasy captures a unique tale of what happens when love in interrupted by forces of nature no one can control. Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett are marvelous in this picture. I remember taking a group of my film critic students to a preview screening of this film. They were able to share their thoughts with a representative of the production company who was planning to offer those comments to director David Fincher.  Nominated for 13 Oscars, this film would carry home 3 including visual effects.

Taken from "Oscar Winning Films (A-Z) That Everyone Should See Before They Die 1.2"

By Noel T. Manning II

If you don't know how to make a good thing last long, this is the movie you should watch. Not stay young forever, not getting richer everyday, not riding cool motorcycles and watching the sea in every Sunday night. Romance is magical but romance is just hard to last long. It's those little lovely details in your memory make you pity and happy. When something good is happening, cherish it. When something good is about to end, don't swear or cry, just let go. Remember those little things that get you emotinoal and move on like a rational human being. Time always travels fast but sometimes, time does slow down a little bit, and we just need to find that rhythm. Daisy didn't die in Benjamin's arms but who can say that the love between Benjamin and Daisy didn't last long. And I think for most people, that kind of love is long enough.

I think where this film looses out is the interaction of the outside world into the story. It's too 'perfect and predictable' without any challenges that might've helped define the characters and progression a bit better. Alcoholism, racism, crime, depression, drugs, politics, etc. In a way it's nice, this fairy tale love story in a utopian past where all are born, live, and die in serenity and peace. But it's also condescending in a way to mask over what so many of us have learned through history and experience still in our modern lives. Especially when the movie is so long, one would expect a bit more 'umph' with Benjamin's experiences and/or occurrences that happen to people around him. Had the movie lost some flotsam/jetsam and shored down to a two hour frame, I may have given it another star. The nice thing with Criterion is the supplemental disc that painstakingly shows the making of this film. Very eye opening as to getting the story to script, and the script to film. And highly impressive all the CGI and arduous acting from all the cast in front of and behind the camera. But, it still doesn't do anything to bolster the story other than exemplify it was more or less a proving ground to see if all the effects and inserts could work. As a romantic fable, it's a nice story that could've worked just as well with Roger Corman type cheat methods. For a tech geek, it's a fascinating treasure hunt trying to locate the seam lines and digital quirks while ignoring the story. But with Forrest Gump, Big, Charlie, Mask, and Boy In The Bubble already having touched upon Benjamin Button. And/or just watch them in reverse for the same effect - Benjamin Buttons wasn't that special of a story. And may have actually worked better had Fincher just went with the script to Pixar with Pitt and Blanchett for a couple of months?
I think it should be renamed, "The Curious Case of 'The Notebook' which Recounts the Time Benjamin Button 'Met Joe Black.'"

The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a fantasy-drama that tells a story of a man who ages in reverse and the love interest throughout his life. This was a critically acclaimed film and the movie critics were spot on. It had a great story,the performances of the cast were great and its themes that it tackled particularly about life's lessons and it isn't about being morally upright nor preachy about it. Added to that,we are also treated about how events in our life are interconnected with one another and everything happens for a purpose whether good and bad. It maybe a three-hour film long but it wasn't a drag nor boring for it will surely entertain the viewer.

This film is heartbreakingly beautiful. Director David Fincher created an Oscar- worthy piece of art. Unfortunately his film was released around the same time as a superb masterwork by Danny Boyle that year, "Slumdog Millionaire"; otherwise I'm sure he would have carried home several golden statuettes.
This is a prime example of what you can make with every resource available to you - painstaking VFX, A-list cast, the best cameras, locations, and a fantastic script.  The pacing may be slow (the only reason it gets 4 stars instead of 5), but it's worth the time investment to allow the story to unfold as it should.

If you're looking for a movie that bends the rules and approaches love in a very poignant way, this is a must-see flick. You'll have to let go of any sense of logic and let the story sweep you into an imaginative journey. From the very beginning and end of Benjamin Button's life, the physical changes seems believable and almost becomes secondary to the love between himself and Daisy.

I'm only mentioning this because I read it in other reviews prior to watching the movie; something I normally don't do and wish I hadn't.  A correlation was made between this movie and "Forrest Gump" and sadly, for me, I was so distracted by that for about the first hour, because I kept trying to find the correlation and couldn't (and I've seen "Forrest Gump" at least 100 times; literally).  In any case, I finally gave up on trying and watched the movie on it's on merit.  That correlation, or certain similarities, DID come to me as the movie progressed, but I sincerely believe that had I not read those reviews, I would not have made the correlation otherwise, as I was so wrapped up in THIS story; which stood entirely on it's own.  It was just as equally and uniquely different as "Forrest Gump", so I'm not crying over spilled milk, because I absolutely LOVED this movie and plan to watch it over, and over, and over again until my one month streaming rental subscription ends, because that's how much I loved it.  I'm an NOT a professional critic either, just a movie lover.  However, IMHO, this movie was so exquisitely acted (and narrated) by both Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett (as always on both counts) as well as the entire cast, and everything from the set designs to the special effects and special effects make-up artistry, to the costumes, lighting, and timing was just perfect in every way.  It is most definitely a bittersweet story, but not one which I found at all depressing as mentioned in another review,  Although I cried many times during the movie, they were indeed both happy and sad tears.  The bottom line is that, in the end, it totally depends on how you look at life and how you deal with it.  If you are cynical or a pessimist, then this movie might well depress you, or you just simply might not enjoy this type of movie.  However, if you have a glimmer of faith, or you believe in fate and that everything happens exactly how and when it's supposed to, or if you're a dreamer, like to fantasize, or you're an optimist, OR if you could ever even begin to imagine living your life in reverse as "Benjamin" lived his, then you just might find the beauty in this story.  At least I did.  Wonderful story, wonderful movie, and I don't know why, of the many other awards it did receive, why it did not garner ALL of them!!! FIVE ***** all the way!!!!!!!!!

fantastic film. fantastic HD release from Criterion.

picture:
very good. almost forgot it was shot on digital camera and not film. looks nigh flawless, though. black levels are great and colors are brownish and old-timey; very fitting to the tone of the movie itself. lines are very clear and crisp and detail is magnificent. consistent picture throughout, no signs of edge halos (wouldn't typically get them from movies made this recently).

audio:
great. It's lossless audio from Criterion. it's Criterion, period. trust them.

overall:
Get it. Great film to just own, and there's a long, very good making-of included along with a few other special features.

A bladder-buster. (Glad I saw it at home.) It was a sentimental, unusual, and well done story, unmuddled by a sound track that got in the way. The only real objection I had to it was when Benjamin just up decides that he can't be a father to his daughter and abandons his family. That was completely out of character for him. Up until then, he had always been depicted as a devoted family man and somebody in complete acceptance of his condition -- and that everyone around him was in acceptance of his condition. It just didn't make logical sense that he would suddenly take off. Maybe the writers needed him to do that in order to satisfy their outline -- a cardinal sin of storytelling. Or maybe they finally realized the movie was getting too long and so had to compress part of his life. Whatever, it was a stupid plot development. The rest of the movie was great, though.

I had originally watched this movie back in college, during my twenties, and thought it was dull and boring. I just didn't get it then, and so put it aside for more energetic and thrilling movies.

Then I watched the movie more recently, in my thirties, and now can appreciate its characters and deliberately slow pace. It is a movie about aging, and therefore is supposed to be thoughtful and slow and even sometimes stale so that the viewer can age with the movie.

I now found the characters both interesting and uniquely fleshed out and flawed, just like real people facing problems with growing old and with a restless yearn to repair certain regrets. I could enjoy this movie because I myself had grown up and experienced regret and guilt and lost dreams. These messages are perfectly conveyed throughout the movie, making it a classic that never grows old.

"The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: "I was born under unusual circumstances." And so begins "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button," adapted from the 1920s story by F. Scott Fitzgerald about a man who is born in his eighties and ages backwards: a man, like any of us, who is unable to stop time. We follow his story, set in New Orleans from the end of World War I in 1918, into the 21st century, following his journey that is as unusual as any man's life can be.

The cast led by Brad Pitt (in his best performance as Benjamin Button), Cate Blanchett (as Daisy), and Taraji P. Henson (in an excellent performance as Queenie) is excellent! The directing by David Fincher (who also directed "Alien 3" (1992), "Seven" (1995, his first teaming with Pitt), "The Game" (1997), "Fight Club" (1999, his second teaming with Pitt), "Panic Room" (2002) & "Zodiac" (2007) is excellent! The screen story (based on Fitzgerald's short story) by Eric Roth & Robin Swicord (who also wrote the screenplay to "Little Women" (1994) & "Memoirs Of A Geisha" (2005) and the screenplay by Roth (who won the Oscar for his screenplay to "Forrest Gump" (1994), he also wrote the story and screenplay to "The Insider" (1999), "Ali" (2001, screenplay), "Munich" (2005, screenplay), & "The Good Shepherd" (2006) is excellent!

The music by Alexandre Desplat (who also did the music to "Syriana" (2005), "The Queen" (2006), & "The Golden Compass" (2007) is excellent! The cinematography by Claudio Miranda is excellent! The film editing by Kirk Baxter & Angus Wall (who also did the film editing to "Zodiac" & "Panic Room") is excellent! The casting by Laray Mayfield (who also did the casting to "Fight Club", "Panic Room", "Zodiac", & "The Incredible Hulk" (2008) is excellent! The production design by Donald Graham Burt (who also did the production design to "Zodiac") is excellent! The art direction by Kelly Curley, Randy Moore (who also did the art direction to the upcoming "G.I. Joe: Rise Of Cobra" (2009), & Tom Reta (who also did the art direction to the upcoming "Surrogates" (2009) is excellent! The set decoration by Victor J. Zolfo (who also did the set decoration to "Zodiac", "Yes Man" (2008) & the upcoming "Terminator: Salvation" (2009) is excellent! The costume design by Jacqueline West (who also did the costume design to the upcoming "State Of Play" (2009) is excellent!

This in my estimate is a 3 1/2 star movie, so if I could give it that here I would have. It's a pretty good movie but not a classic or even a great film. The best part of this film is the first 90 minutes from Benjamin's birth as an old man, and on down untill he reaches maybe his 50's. The film is pretty much exceptional and wonderful during it's first half, but it's less interesting as it moves onward. It is unique, touching, and generally incredible to see Benjamin begin as a small baby and yet have all the characteristics of an old man. The aging effects of the central character are amazing. It is incredible to watch him grow younger, learning who he is, how to walk, and how to cope with his unusual sort of cycle of life. The film is truly great during these segments. Many of the characters following along in this portion of the film are memorable and interesting as well. But by the time Benjamin progresses downward into his 40's and younger, the aging process seems to weaken. Benjamin stays looking between 40 and 20 far too long, but what really doesn't work well is that some of the characters who were in their 30's and 40's during the earlier part of the film don't seem to look as old as they should some 50 years later. The effects people did a very good job at making Brad Pitt look 20 though, It was very convincing. Sadly though the film seems less interesting during it's second half, and it does have too many simularities with Forrest Gump, which in my assesment forces it to take a hit or two here and there. I really felt it was a better than average film and for it's first half deserved to be in Oscar territory.

This is a case of style over substance if I ever saw one, a movie that is all dressed up with no where to go. There is no point and no plot, but everything from the music to the dialog, asks us to suspend our critical thought, and take it on faith that it is as profound as it thinks it is. But then what could we expect from a movie based on nothing but a cute gimmick. "Hey let's have a guy who gets younger as life goes on". Everything that happens in this movie is predictable given this premise. For instance, of course he would meet a young girl, fall in love, and have a baby with her when their ages meet. This is in no way profound or interesting, it is just the most obvious gimmick to stack on top of the first one, and unfortunately how the movie would play out was obvious to me after only the first 10 minutes. The next two hours are just painful to watch, as the movie never deviates from the expected path, with no surprises and no depth, but still dripping with hollow emotional cues of false profundity, very much like those of a religious service. One star might be a little low but it is appropriate, given how overrated this movie is.

The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is about a boy born with the body of an old man. His father abandons him on the steps of a home for the elderly, and a care-taker takes him in as her own. Benjamin grows younger as time goes by, and just like anyone else, experiences things like love, loss, war, and death. The plot chiefly follows Benjamin's life, but the story contains a lot of interesting little pieces of other character's lives. It's sort of a study of people and their lives and how everything flows together.

In between everything else, the film is a love story between Benjamin and Daisy, a young girl he met as an old man. Eventually, their ages meet in the middle, and they begin the relationship they've waited their whole lives to have. This premise might be a little bizarre and off-putting to some, but this is exactly the kind of strange love story, that I can appreciate.

The film moves slowly and quietly. The effects in this movie are subtle, but that is exactly why they are impressive. Those looking for purely a great love story will get it... in time. But if you can appreciate a long, quiet movie about life, with a bit a quirk, this film may be for you. Just get your tissues ready.

What would like be like if you could only grow younger? The Curious Case of Benjamin Button attempts to answer that question in a beautiful & exquisite way.
Without going way into depth - this really is an amazing film.  It succeeds because it brings the content to life in a realistic way that really draws the viewer in.
Even more importantly, there is a lot to be learned from watching this movie.  It is a long meditative film that really makes you think.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button was directed by David Fincher & is loosely based on the 1922 short story of the same name by F. Scott Fitzgerald.
The film stars Brad Pitt & Cate Blanchett. To keep things simple Benjamin Button (Pitt) is born a very old man. Throughout the film he grows younger.
His love interest is Daisy Fuller (Blanchett).  Its interesting to watch because their love seems very pure.  The characters story is very unique but it seems like an
ordinary love story.  In a sense,  Benjamin Button's life is not that much different from a normal existence. A person is born, they live, they love, and they sail into the abyss.
This is life and the majority of the experience depends greatly on personal perspective.  The movie is long but it is a worthwhile adventure.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a good film for mediative & thoughtful times.

The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a sad movie, but perfect in a sense where the story comes full circle.  The director did a wonderful job outlining the parallels between the two characters.  Button who starts life as an old man, who travels in the reverse of aging, and his female counterpart played by Cate Blanchett who ages "normally." The concept of time and age are intricately woven throughout the movie.  The characters age in their different ways from the 40s up to present day when we learn of the fall of our characters.  However, I have not read the short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald, so I'm not exactly sure how close it ties to the book.  The only other downside is that it's a long movie, but doesn't feel long, but there are some slow moving parts.  Overall, great movie. Definitely worth owning.
This movie delivers.  I found it to be exciting in spots, funny and very moving.  The acting and effects worked together for once.

THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON is stunning.  The story, the acting, the effects, the craftsmanship of the filmmakers--everything hits on all cylinders.  And with the extra features available with THE CRITERION COLLECTION, the viewer learns about the remarkable technology that allowed Brad Pitt to play young (meaning "old") Benjamin by digitally placing an animated face on another actor's body.  Then the viewer learns how "cosmetic" effects were used to make Pitt and costar Cate Blanchett look much, much younger. The disc containing the special features, where everything is discussed about the film--from its inception to post-production--is actually longer than the film itself, but well worth taking the time to watch.  It's as spellbinding as the haunting tale of Benjamin Button--a person who was born old, and ages backwards through decade after decade of life primarily in New Orleans.  And over the course of the story, some very compelling and interesting characters weave in and out of Benjamin's life in grand fashion.

And what a story!  As director David Fincher advises in a must-see audio commentary, THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON is not a "love story", it's a "death story."  As the story begins, we find Cate Blanchett's Daisy character literally on her death bed as Katrina bears down on NOLA.  As she has her daughter Caroline (Julia Ormond) read aloud from Benjamin's personal diary, the story moves back to New Orleans during World War I, to the dedication of a new clock for the city's train station, whereby Gateau, the blind clockmaker, has installed a clock that runs backwards--"So that all the sons we lost in the war might return to us."  We then move to the evening of Armistice Day, the night a withered and monster-looking Benjamin is born, with his dazed father (Jason Flemying) literally leaving the newborn on the doorstep of the local old folks' home.  Thus an ancient-looking Benjamin literally grows up surrounded by death, as inhabitant after inhabitant dies, only to be replaced by other inhabitants who die.  Benjamin's childhood may be the best, most entertaining part of a most entertaining film, because all the characters that come into Benjamin's life are so delightful and fun to watch.  (Two of the most compelling characters are Queenie (Taraji P. Henson), Benjamin's adoptive mother, and the hysterical Captain Mike (Jared Harris), who gives adolescent Benjamin his first job on a tugboat, and a most interesting coming-of-age evening.)  Of course it's during his childhood that Benjamin meets 7-year-old Daisy; both are immediately drawn to one another, and as Daisy so wondrously states, they spend the next few years preparing to "meet in the middle."

The story moves on from Benjamin's childhood, when he leaves New Orleans at age 17 (yet he looks 60) to adventure on Captain Mike's boat literally all over the world.  Before World War II erupts, he has his first love affair in Russia with Elizabeth Abbott (Tilda Swinton is terrific), the wife of an English diplomat, and during the war Benjamin experiences suffering and death as Captain Mike's tugboat is destroyed at sea.  Benjamin returns to New Orleans following the war, and as the years unfold his youthful looks begin to coincide with Daisy's (who is in a ballerina troupe traveling the world), until an injury ends her career, and in her thirties she returns to New Orleans, and Benjamin and Daisy begin their lives together.  There is pending heartbreak because, as Benjamin laments, "Nothing ever lasts", and over the decade of the Sixties Daisy ages while Benjamin looks younger; a daughter is born in 1968, and a year later, Benjamin informs his soulmate, "She needs a father, not a playmate."  He quietly leaves early one dawn, and we don't find him again until 13 years later, when he shows up unexpectedly at Daisy's dance studio; both Benjamin and Daisy are in their fifties, yet Daisy looks middle-aged, while Benjamin barely looks 20.  There is a brief romantic encounter, then the story doesn't pick up again until Daisy receives a call from Child Services, asking for her assistance with a confused boy who doesn't know who he is.  Daisy moves back to the nursing home and becomes Benjamin's caretaker, until in 2003, appearing as an infant, he dies in Daisy's arms.  So indeed, THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON is a "death story", but it is also a rich celebration of life.

THE CRITERION COLLECTION version of this film is enthusiastically recommended.  David Fincher has made a masterpiece, richly detailed and marvelously crafted; THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON could very well be this generation's "Citizen Kane".
--D. Mikels, Esq.

The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is based on a story by F. Scott Fitzgerald about a man, born in 1918, who ages in reverse.  Benjamin's baby body looks like an 86-year-old with the same illnesses common to that age.  As the years pass, the body becomes younger.  The film explores the conundrums of this condition, such as  falling in love and fathering a child.  Brad Pitt plays Benjamin simply and admirably, assisted by technology to give him an aged body and by younger actors in closing scenes.  Cate Blanchett plays Daisy, a dancer (she does almost all of her own dancing).  Their love relationship begins when both are adolescents; yet he appears to be an old codger, upsetting Daisy's grandmother.  They are perfectly matched when they are in their forties.  But then a child is born and decisions must be made, as they know Benjamin will become gradually younger.  The story is told in a nursing home in New Orleans in 2005.  Hurricane Katrina is raging as a dying Daisy has her daughter read Benjamin's diary to her.  We see the flashbacks of his jaunt through the 20th century, and Daisy's daughter discovers her identity.  The film evokes contemplation on that century and on the nature of time itself.

This movie was wonderfully done. They recreated points in history that looked amazing. The special effects of reverse aging looked incredible, to the point where you almost wanted to skip ahead just to see how it would turn out. The acting is phenomenal and the story sucks you right in. This was a tremendous film and definitely worth owning. Needless to say, Criterion always treats their films well. It costs a little extra, but it's always worth it.

I bought this movie at my wifes urging.  She told me about the concept (someone born old and getting younger over a lifetime and dying as a baby) and said, from the parts of the movie shes seen, she thought it was a wonderful movie. I understand that it was up for a bizillion awards and so on. . . good for them.  I thought the second dvd with the "how they did stuff" was FAR more interesting than the movie.  I think most guys would feel the same way I do about it - a real cure for insomnia.  The wife LOVED it though.  By the way . . . I gave it 3 stars BECAUSE the wife loved it. My wife and I truly enjoyed this movie.  I love the twist on reality and how it reminds us of many things including the ever-true, but often not listened to lesson that life is short and each of our journeys are unique, yet forever connected.

I watched The Curious Life of Benjamin Button for the fourth time last weekend. I think the story line is so interesting and very romantic.  I wonder what it would be like to live life backward as Benjamin Button did.

This movie has to be watched right from the beginning.  The beginning holds the whole purpose for Benjamin's journey to begin.

I am sure I will watch this a few more times before my time is up.  I highly recommend anyone to get lost in this movie and I am sure you will feel the same.

Here are bullets of why it is bad:

"The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" is a drama fantasy film enriched with an enchanting story of love and adventure.

It is a unique account of reverse aging where Benjamin Button (Brad Pitt) is born with elderly characteristics and comes to know Daisy Fuller (Cate Blanchett) at the nursing home he lives at with his adoptive parents who are on the staff there, and where Daisy visits her grandmother who is a resident.

Pitt and Blanchett have inherent screen chemistry which sees them teamed up again having previously starred together in the 2006 film "Babel".

The narrative is multilayered with both Daisy and Benjamin having their own tangents yet they come together and shift apart at several junctions in the movie.

It is a unique film that is very satisfying with a masterfully constructed story.

Nicholas R.W. Henning - Australian Author

Movie: Full of excellent performances, this story is complex, yet simply and clearly told. The pacing is perfect, and the already excellent script is brought to life beautifully by director David Fincher. 10/10.

Video: Criterion is known for stunning, true-to-filmmaker-intent video transfers, and this is no exception. Shot digitally, this movie shows none of that artificial digital flatness, and feature perfect contrast and outstanding color reproduction. The whole thing is razor-sharp, but naturally so, giving an incredibly lifelike image. 10/10.

Audio: The sound design, like that of all David Fincher films, is incredible, and this DTS-HD MA 5.1 track (I don't know why the cover says "Dolby Digital 5.1," but rest assured it is actually a DTS-HD Master Audio track) reproduces it wonderfully. The sound here is clear and enveloping, with perfect LFE output and surround activity. Dialogue and music are well-prioritized. 10/10.

Special Features: Criterion and David Fincher are both known for providing a wealth of special feature on their releases, and so it is no surprise that release features just that. A massive ammount of special features, all of which are informative and interesting. 10/10.

Overall: Yeah. Perfect. 10/10.

THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE CRITERION COLLECTION VERSION ONLY

This DVD set is incredible.  First of all, there is an incredible amount of extras, features/commentary.  In fact, there is a making of type documentary which is worth the price of admission.  It is about as long or longer than the actual movie and really makes you appreciate the movie even more.  It explains how the script knocked around for a long time -- mostly because it would be impossible to film.  Once it was decided that the movie would be made, the process would have be be created as there was no way to actually make the movie (imagine Brad Pitt, 80+ years old, the size of a 7 year old boy).  It's a truly incredible story.  I don't want to explain, but one of my favorite scenes from the movie was filmed on a set, and I had no idea.  The commentary is also excellent.

Buy this DVD set.  Watch the movie, then check out the special features.  You won't regret spending a penny if you do.

The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button (The Criterion Collection) [Blu-ray] I purchased this movie on blu ray the criterion collection edition and was amazed at th quality and attention to detail that went with this edition. I really suggest buying that veraion of the movie because of the diffence in quality i can recognize more depth in the sound in my in home theatre with 10,000 watts the highs and lows are crystal clear.

This recasts F. Scott Fitzgerald's original (which I have not read) somewhat, but the format works. Here, Benjamin's story appears through diaries, postcards, and reminiscences, many years after his curious death. That adds modern characters and plot to the story, but allows the movie to skip through his life, selecting the scenes that contribute to his curious story.

The basic theme is star-crossed lovers. More accurately, crossed lives, living their lives in opposite directions. They meet when each is just a few years old, but that friendship lasts their lifetime. As each approaches the other from the opposite end of the calendar, though, they have a tragically short time for a normal relationship. Although their relationship has long breaks, they continue it anyway, even when it can't be normal. Parts of this will resonate strongly with anyone who's kept love alive even when bodies and minds fail.

That love pervades this movie. After massive rejection and betrayal in the first hours of his life, Benjamin is surrounded by the most loving people imaginable and by acceptance that requires disbelief to be suspended. (Suspend it, it's worth it.) Queenie, his adoptive mother, exemplifies that best, with a loving devotion that never wavers - no matter what. Daisy loves him equally, but shows more human weakness in bearing the burden of caring for him. Captain Mike and the crew accept him, as do others.

Then, Benjamin looks clearly at the end of life, the failing powers, the lossess, and eventual death. By turning Benjamin's life around, however, this story shows a symmetry between start and end, almost an equation that needs to be balanced. If one word stated the core of this movie, it would be "acceptance." This is not just about accepting others, whatever their condition, but accepting the whole of the human condition.

-- wiredweird

This is a great film with an unusual and interesting concept of love, time, and aging. I have watched this film several times to explore the challenging relationships among the characters. The impact of time on an aging individual is so much more striking when contrasted with the aging process in the reverse. This film, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button unravels on the canvas of a sick bed before Huricane Katrina.

This story is about a daughter learning about the true origins of her father by being surreptitiously made to read her father's diary. Her father is Mr. Benjamin Button who is "born under curious circumstances": born old and aging backwards. Themes of family, the purpose of life, unfulfilled love, fate, end of life and death were principal to the plot with fate being a major element. But the portrayal of key relationships was not sufficient to match the message. Noticeable was the amount 'dark' scenes: there was an air of perpetual night. Overall the story is a wonderful reflection on living, love and relationships. Unfortunately the greater messages of the movie are much undeveloped or contradicting. It was unfortunate that the beauty of the picture was complimented by these incomplete relationships and messages making the movie wonderfully incomplete.

The theme of fate is the source of one of many comparisons to Forest Gump, but unlike Forest Gump a review of destiny is mostly encumbered so as to be disguised. The comparisons are fair considering that the movie is essentially filled with vignettes of key relationships in Mr. Benjamin Button's life and the philosophical, moral and spiritual lessons he adopts from each. His reverse aging almost appears as a secondary or tertiary theme compared to the attempts to philosophy the meaning of living. I would compare this movie to a cross between Forest Gump and A River Runs Through It.

Revealing the summary knowledge and wisdom of these supporting characters often felt manipulated and palpably advertised so as to lose emotional effect. At other times thought provoking message were distracted by titillating interactions. It felt as if `sex' was being use to attract attention to the message which it was obscuring. There was an abruptness to many of the key messages of the film which was in part due to a lack of depth in key relationships. Exemplary of this is the depictions of the relationship of Benjamin with his father. Also curious were the reemerging past relationships which seemed awkwardly placed.
____________________________________
I found many of the messages contradicting. One contradiction was that of accepting ones fate (Artist Captain), but then being unwilling to deal with the consequences of his life by living out his life with the love of his life despite is reverse aging. I found similarities and contradictions in that his daughter was easily made to forgive him for abandoning, something which he was unable to do with his own father. His moral character only stood when he was with the love of his life (Paris Gazebo), otherwise he found little contradiction with using women to fulfill his needs.

I haven't read the book prior to seeing the movie which is something I don't normally do. So, I don't know how faithful this adoption is. However, I really enjoyed watching this film.

The story of Benjamin Button is sweet, different, unique and eventually very sad. I guess that is inevitable for someone who was born very different from the rest of us. I'm not going to retell the plot as I'm sure a lot of reviewers did so masterfully, I'm going to say the reason why I liked this movie despite my distaste for *sad* and *depressing* endings without giving too much away.

What made this story stand out for me isn't just the unique and mysterious circumstances surrounding Benjamin's birth but the moral behind the story. We live in a world that is fascinated with Youth and Beauty so much to the point of obsession. In a world where Cosmetic Surgeries and anti aging products are multi/billion if not trillion trades I think many people with gladly give everything they have/own to be in the shoes of Benjamin Button. Imagine growing Younger instead of older ? Imagine becoming more beautiful and healthy by the day instead of the other way round. I know it is impossible but if it were wouldn't you take it ?

What I like about this film is that it keeps things realistic, It shows the *bad* side of getting younger. The side that the media doesn't show, the side that people don't know about or pay attention to or take for granted. Imagine if you were getting younger and younger by the year and everyone around is getting older. You won't be able to see your kids grow into adults, you won't be able to attend their graduations, school activities, or even weddings because by that time you'll be a child. You won't be able to age gracefully, see your grandchildren or die peacefully in your sleep as an old man/woman. I know many people wouldn't consider dying as an infant in their quest of getting younger but lets face it people aren't immortal and the only way to be forever young is to die in your youth.

Just the idea of retiring to teenage hood and childhood instead of prime age and elderly is very exhausting to me. All the things that you'll have to sacrifice might not be worth it. I'm sure Benjamin Button wished he could be like the rest of his peers and age gracefully instead of the other way round but he had to submit and be content by his share, he rarely if ever complained about it and I admire his character a lot for that. I know there was a lot of implying on it but I was hoping that the author would somehow manage to make poor Benjamin age normally so he could live the rest of his life with the woman he loves and watch his daughter grow but still I couldn't complain because despite it being sad and depressing it does reflect the message it is trying to send.

The Cast choice is perfect (IMO) I'm not a fan of Brad Pitt but this has to be one of my favorite movies by him along with Seven Years in Tibet. Cate Blanchett is a superb actress and I really liked her role here. This is the second Pitt/Blanchett collaboration and I liked it better than Babel.

I recommend this movie for anyone who likes drama or is looking for something different. As long as you don't mind the somehow depressing ending it shouldn't be a problem however if you are looking for an action packed film with swashbuckling Brad Pitt then Oh, well you'll be greatly disappointed.
this is an awesome movie. i thought that 5the story and the actors were great one of brad pitt's best performance.  this is a must see. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend that you do

In some ways, despite its Oscar nomination for best picture, this was quite the disaster. Though the acting is good, and the set design and cinematography lovely, the problem lies in the changes to the original short story it was taken from, which was profound and eloquent, and often hilarious, particularly in the story's opening pages, where we meet Benjamin born as a full-sized old man, with all his cranky faculties in tact :-) Why the filmmakers decided to abandon the original ideas of the classic story and create a BB character that, to my way of thinking, seemed like one of the most boring and lifeless persons (personality-wise) to ever occupy the screen, I'll never know. And the movie is slow. Not that I mind slow in the least; some of my favorite films are slow in a beautiful, mesmerizing way, just not this kind of slow. As one late-night comedian put it: "Over the weekend, I went to see The Curious Case of Benjamin ZZZZZZZZZZZZZ..." That pretty much sums it up for me. At least director Fincher turned out a much smarter, much better product with his next film, "The Social Network."

Absolutely beautiful, amazing, stunning movie. It broke my heart many times, but also made me smile and laugh with pleasure at key parts. By the end you *feel* like you've lived this entire lifetime with Benjamin. This is one of those movies you never forget, and remember always. One of the best movies I've seen in a very long time. I will remember it and it's story and lessons, as I continue to live out my own life. Hopefully as fully as Benjamin always tried to live out his.

A poor man's Forrest Gump with an inexplicable gimmick tossed in. This really didn't need to be half as long as it was, and all the major scenes seemed like window dressing while the dull in-between moments were stretched out for as long as possible. It had a few charming scenes and some legitimately funny bits (especially the old man recounting his experiences with lightning) but give any film nearly three hours and a huge budget; the law of averages says it's bound to stumble across a few of those by sheer chance. Many of the character moments were forced and stiff, and there was almost zero chemistry between Blanchett and Pitt to back up their supposed lifelong passion for one another. Wrapping the whole story up into Hurricane Katrina just felt cheap and needless. A real disappointment.
