I understand that the main character was aging backwards, but does that have to mean that he is born "mature" and stays that way?  Have these writers never heard about character development.  If the main character doesn't grow, change, then a lot of exciting things better be happening all around him.  The choices that the writers made were poor.  In one of the user reviews someone points out the lack of conflict, which is one of the big problems.  I'll put it a bit more simply.  If this guy were aging forward, would there be any reason to make a movie about him?  No!  Even Fitzgerald's original story is more interesting.  It has Benjamin behave his age as he grows younger.  He is curmudgeonly as an old man, full of himself in middle age and flirty and stupid in youth.  He lives his life instead of staying basically the same aloof blank throughout.  My problem with this guy is that he doesn't react to the things happening in his life - i.e. he doesn't behave like a human being.  Everything gets tied up in neat little packages.  He leaves his wife, but she finds a "good man" to help her raise their child.  His lover swims the English channel as an old woman.  He "forgives" his father.  When he is dying his wife is almost magically there to take care of him.  It's too neat.  The special effects are good - my has CGI come a long way - but they're good in Transformers too and no one would claim that's a good movie.  But Brad Pitt is HOT and that does help.  So not a complete waste of time.

Heh. An Overlong, romance infested demonstration of special effects and how they benefit the film.

Special Effects?

Boo-Yah

Lots?

Yes

Realistic?

Miles from Realistic, My Friends

GOOD Special Effects Are Supposed To Be Realistic.

Now My Criticism for the rest of the film:
COMPLETE BOGUS
EVERY SINGLE PERFORMANCE WAS A LOAD OF WET POOP
The Script Was Something Found In A Screenwriter's Trash Can

If You Still Want To View It, Rent It Before You Buy It.

My husband and I just finished watching this movie and WOW...its a definite 10!  I never dreamed that they could pull off the storyline and make it believable...but they did...and you believed every word of it.  This is by far Brad Pitts best performance and I have enjoyed almost all of his movies (Joe Black was his weakest role). Cate Blanchett also amazing as always.  The special effects (aging and getting younger) were simply awesome.  Flawless. My husband and I rarely agree on rating a movie, but this time we both agreed it was a full 10.  I never watch movies more than once, but I'm going to watch it again tomorrow.  Do yourself a favor...watch this movie.  It will stand the test of time.  It should have gotten more oscars...Slumdog wasn't even close to this one.

Where does one begin??  This movie can easily put someone in a coma.  If you have insomnia, this just might do the trick in getting you to sleep!  Horrible film!  I was really hoping this one would knock everybody out of the park but this movie just drags on and on and on...

The best parts of the movie are really when the film is taking place during Hurricane Katrina and even at that, you're lefting wondering at the end of the movie why they even put it in there.

Aside from the hum drum and depressing subject matter, the special effects deserve at least one star.  They truly are unbelievable.  Except special effects can't carry a movie!  One only need to check out a myriad of other films that have tried to do the same thing-Battlefield Earth anyone??

Steer clear of this turkey!
One of the best D.V.D's I have ever seen. I would rate this one 6 stars!

Director David Fincher always has kept his worldview dark and depressing, and "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" is no exception. He again directs Brad Pitt (previously in Fincher's Seven), this time as a man inexplicably born with all the physical characteristics of an 80 year old who then ages in reverse. All this while his mental faculties work in standard time, so he gains an old man's lifetime of memories. While Fincher usually pulls at the strings that manipulate us into staring at the darkness of man (think Zodiac), this time he goes right for melodramatic heartstrings. It's not always a perfect fit. While Fincher has, as usual, made a gorgeously rich looking movie, there are times when you wonder why Benjamin was just free to wander aimlessly through life, not having scientists and doctors swarming around him. And while the story of the clock at the beginning of the movie is a poignant allegory and therefore seemed useful to the film, the element of Hurricane Katrina as a timing device seemed crowbarred in. Will that stop you from needing at least one box of Kleenex to make it through this movie? Not at all. "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" is a moving story of how aging takes us through life, both in love and in tragedy. "We all end up in diapers," says Daisy (Cate Blanchett, amazing as always) who tries to make sense of her love with a man that can only drift away. The cast is uniformly strong throughout, with Taraji P. Henson as Queenie getting the best 'wisdom' lines, a scene stealing Tilda Swinton as Benjamin's first love affair and Jared Harris as Capt Mike, the swashbuckling tugboat man with the heart of an artist. The overall tragedy is speckled with bits of humor and lots of deep love. In the end, though, the movie belongs to Brad Pitt. Through make-up, CGI and other devices, he portrays Benjamin as man out of time, trying to comprehend the way life has changed the world as he moves in reverse of everyone around him. Even though he is absent from the last 30 minutes, his presence is felt in the way Daisy takes him back to where everything began. Sad and beautiful all at the same time, "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" is a grand movie that falls short of greatness; nonetheless it is worth your time.
This movie had very good cinematography and decent aging and reverse aging effects as well as good acting.  Unfortunately these could not help a very boring movie.

ok.... to be honest here i reeeeaaaally wanna give this movie a two.  Why?  Because after i left the theater I could have sworn i had just paid to see Forest Gump again (this might even be considered a spoiler) I'm not even exaggerating when i say the story lines are just about completely identical.

I gave it an extra star because it did provide some interesting characters... i suppose the movie was sad but to be honest i couldn't see it through my aggravation... don't get me wrong... i enjoyed Forest Gump... but damn..

Why is this film dull? Could it be that the characters are empty, and that they passively coast through the story, meekly awaiting their fate? The fact that Ben Button is growing younger might be expected to twist his psychology in an interesting way: unfortunately we are given no insight into this psychology. He takes the first manual job that comes along, a business is bequeathed to him, and his imagination is limited to pursuing his childhood sweetheart - all this challenges him to the most minimal degree, and he is asked to make virtually no interesting decisions. Yes, he is growing younger, but this seems to make almost no impact upon him, nor upon those around him. The character appears to be a very unreflective and retiring person; what's more, Brad Pitt delivers a performance that is curious in being bereft of emotion - was he afraid of ruining his elaborate make-up? Kate Blanchett's character has a bit more spunk, but her restlessness is extinguished mid-film, and she too is reduced to a pretty well silent witness to proceedings from then on. There is virtually no internal, nor much external, conflict between the protagonists, nor between them and the world.

All this amounts to an idea in search of a story. Imagine if you were asked to watch a monkey being born old, then slowly growing younger as time went on, until finally petering out. As a three minute video on Youtube this would be (kind of) interesting. If it went on for three hours, I don't think many viewers would last the distance. Without a story, the novelty wears thin - as is the case here.

With comparisons to to the far superior "Forrest Gump" aplenty, David Fincher's VERY loosely based adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's short story manages to stand, though wobbly, on its own. From a technical aspect, "Benjamin" is flawless, a masterpiece of technical wizardry and attention to detail. Yet, from the standpoint of a story, it's sadly lacking any kind of emotion, which is surprising and ironic because the actors certainly convey enough emotion. It's just that these emotions never fully involve the viewer like it did in "Forrest Gump." We're not really sure if we even knew who Benjamin Button really was, even though we spend nearly 3 hours with him. This also goes for the character of Daisy. As a result, we're not fully convinced or even that involved with the story, which is a shame because it's a very interesting set-up: a man is born old and continues to age backwards. It's a brilliant and commendable premise that I applaud director David Fincher and screenwriter Eric Roth (who also penned "Gump") for attempting to tackle such an odd non-Hollywood story involving themes of mortality. Unfortunately, the end result isn't as beautiful as the picture itself presents to be.

Though this is a failed masterpiece, it is definitely worth seeing. When something this strange comes out of Hollywood and everyone's paying attention (mainly because of the lead actors), it time to rejoice that film is still able to be creative.

I had heard so much hype about The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, I had to see it even though I rarely watch Brad Pitt movies, not being a particular fan of his work. Usually, when I have low expectations of a movie, which I had about this one (it sounded preposterous to me, but I simply wanted to quell my curiosity), I end up liking it far more than if I had high or higher expectations. However, this movie broke that mold for me.

There are a hundred thousand stories yet to be told to entertain us into oblivion. This is one that should have been left untold or given to a different group of people to bring it to life. I would have given it one star, but I gave it two because there were some extraordinary performances outside of the main character that do not deserve to be ignored.

I think the director of this movie made some odd choices in putting the final version together. Button is born old and ages backward. If you can buy that "genetic anomaly," I suppose you wouldn't look too closely at how much opportunity was wasted after his birth. There is no explanation for his sudden piano-playing ability, no education to speak of, no indication that Button was aware of his odd situation until, suddenly, Brad Pitt appears in the role and just as suddenly, he is gorgeous, well-muscled, and a heart throb. I guess the whole thing transcended my ability to process the "outside-the-box" growth issue inherent in this story. I just thought it was clumsy and unendearing.

There is no doubt in my mind that a much better story lay somewhere in that picture. A different director, producer, actor, perhaps. Tweaking the story to make more sense with better communication between Button and those around him as the story unfolds perhaps. As it was, it appeared to me, to be a messy story and another two hours of my life wasted when I could have been watching something far more worthwhile. I am not unaware of the popularity of this movie amongst much more esteemed reviewers here at Amazon.com than I am. But watching it from a director's eye, I could almost write a book about how many things were wrong with this movie. If a movie has character, I can always forgive those wrong things. The only curious thing about this movie, is that it made it to the movie theaters and so many people raved about it. Humanity never fails to surprise and astound me.

This is not the typical movie I like to watch, but a friend of mine said it reminded him of Forrest Gump so I decided to check it out. The storyline is about a man being born as an old man who ages backwards as people around him get older. I did see a few similarities with Gump, like when Benjamin goes off adventuring and major events are happening around him. There is a good cast of characters and Pitt delivers his normal better than average performance, but what kills this movie is the female lead actress. She comes across as cold, selfish, and unloving and she wasn't the best thing to look at either which might of made her tolerable. Since this movie is, at the bottom of it all, a love story, it's hard to like it if you don't like the girl.

For a character study to be successful, one needs to LIKE the characters. Not possible here. Benjamin is cold, unfeeling, and abandons his wife when she needs him most. Benjamin practically never speaks during the entire movie and is void of any emotion throughout. And the wife...a loose, amoral person who sleeps with anyone and is always gloomy and depressed. All in all, this movie is simply an exercise in special effects and make-up, period. For anything else, Benjamin Button SUCKS.  Steer clear of this turkey.

This is a great movie to see on a big screen. Outstanding cinematography. Excellent acting and story. Although a lot of critics didn't really like this film, I was very moved by it. It's a great love story.

This film has Cate Blanchett and Tilda Swinton, two actresses destined to become Hollywood legends because of their incredible acting ability.  It also has Brad Pitt, destined to become a Hollywood legend because he is some 'serious' eye candy.  But almost three hours of "Forrest Gump For The Twenty-first Century" when we just got over that first piece of crap...I dunnnnoooooo.  Watch at your own risk.

There are some movies that I just love completely the second I'm walking out of the theater. Then there are movies I just hate. And there are also movies that I have slightly mixed feelings about when the credits start to roll, and that's what Benjamin Button is for me. It's been 3 days since I've seen it, and like Children of Men or History of Violence before it, it's only grew fonder with time.

As I was sitting in the theater, I was mesmorized by what I've been watching...and quite sure this would be my absolute favorite movie of the year. Then around the midway point the film kind of lost me for a little. I didn't like the choices some characters were making...but looking back on it now, I think it probably serves the overall movie better. But while watching the movie the first time, I was a little annoyed. That's why I think the movie will play a lot better on future viewings.

Yet, I've only seen it once, so that's how I have to review it. It really is a beautiful movie, and the themes are some I can really connect with; "Nothing Lasts" and "how one little insignificant choice can alter things in ways you'd never imagine" and "regret". The movie really is the Anti-Forest Gump if you think about it. Both movie's are about one man's incredible life.....but while Gump might leave you feeling great, Button might leave you feeling like your dog just died (without resorting to manipulative crap like Marley and Me!). The movie didn't really have that one "CRY HERE" moment...but I was honestly fighting back manly tears for a good long while on this one (nothing fell mind you!).
Cate and Brad are fantastic in this one, and the FX are pretty much as flawless as they come (definitely the best of the year).

I've intentionally left this review as vague as possible, because I don't want to spoil it for you. I'm not sure if this movie is for everyone. The crowd sounded pretty mixed as I was walking out of the theater, and i know my wife did not like it. It's almost 3 hours long, and while I didn't feel it, my wife was ready for it to be over after the first hour...also, she doesn't like Cate for whatever odd reason (I LOVE Cate and thought she was amazing in it).

So anyway, for me, it's one of the best movies of the year. It's not my current favorite, but I think this is the kind that will get better each time I see it. With that said, I give the movie a solid A-/A. Highly recommended, but probably not for everyone.
Never expected a movie to have this kid of reaction in me. Great Movie that moves all your senses, you will cry, you will laught.  I really really recomend everyone should see it at least once

A little tedious and long. It covered the  relationship issue well, but I believe that there are many more questions and issues that could have been raised with more detail - body image, aging, feelings and thought going on in his mind, and more that I can't think of right now. In some ways it was too predictable, when I left the room and returned I could easily guess what had happened. I didn't even bother to push pause. Acting was acceptable, but not great. Generally, the kind of movie during which you can make a sandwich.

Beautiful story.  May seem slow for others, however, it is intended to be viewed at a leisurely pace and enjoyed like good wine, one sip at a time. Keeps you on edge, wondering what's going to happen next.  Ending will break your heart.

Three hours long -- a pointless movie.  The make-up was terrible too.  The whole thing was unbelievable and incredibly boring.  The only thing curious about this case of Benjamin Button is why the film was made and why it received Academy Award recognition in the first place.

I have to admit I was skeptical about this film when I watched it, but it only took a couple of minutes for it to fully get my attention.

I think that other than the amazing CGI work in the movie, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button has a really good timing, I couldn't believe a movie this long will keep me interested all the way.

It is an interesting look on life and gives you a new perspective on aging.

Sometimes I felt that Mr. Depp had problems acting as an old man, but the CGI made sure to make it really believable, making it almost flaw-less and outstanding digital and cinematographic work.

(As a side note, I really enjoyed the idea of how optimistic the character was as he was raised in a place where death is a "common visitor" making him enjoy every day in life like wine drops in a bottle)
Somehow, the english version did not work in my 1:5 dolby surround mode. I have to switch over to the french version. It would be perfect if not due to this blemmish

Not since "Meet Joe Black" have I been so moved by a Brad Pitt film or performance. This movie had such heart. My husband and I sat riveted for two nights (we split it up to watch on weeknights).

The love between Daisy and Benjamin was beautiful and touching.  Benjamin's life was quiet, yet very interesting. I was moved by his generosity of spirit toward his biological father. Daisy & Benjamin's relationship plays out and makes your heart soar to the sky. While it was a tearjerker to watch at times, especially at the end, and I had a lump in my throat, we did not find the movie depressing or a downer. There is the natural cycle to any love.

Blanchett and Pitt are wonderful together. They have great chemistry.

This is a paradox: great actors, beautiful cinematography, original stroryline but somehow it does not gel and become a great movie. Indeed the central premise of the movie, a man aging backwards simply makes the whole thing too weird with its realistic tone. It is also extremely slow moving in an unnecessary way. Simply because time is limitless does not mean that a movie can go on forever. It is still beautiful to watch but kind of boring, which was maybe the idea also.

I think anything is believable; it's all in the way the story is told. 'The Curious Case of Benjamin Button' is just such a story. And besides, we want to believe in that which touches the heart, scares us half to death or brings sidesplitting laughter. This is why we love to watch movies. It is why the best of them appear to be timeless.

This film is excellent on every level. The story was handled perfectly. It is a rich and expansive tale. One might think that time is the subject here, but in truth, it is nothing more than another great love story. `Nothing more' because it doesn't get lost in it's circumstances. The direction of David Fincher wrings every bit of energy and emotion from the cast that allows this story to thrive.

Brad Pitt crafts an unforgettable performance as 'Benjamin Button'. It is perhaps, his finest work to date. He creates an even-tempered, and sophisticated man.
A man who thirsts for a knowledge and understanding of a world that seems upside down, but that also has dropped great compassion on his doorstep.

Taraji Henson is outstanding as the mother that recognizes beauty, the future and the hand of god in her son's disposition. Mahershalalhashbaz Ali compliments Hensen's 'Queenie' as 'Tizzy', the other man in her life. Jared Harris is 'Captain Mike' who in the proverbial split-second decision becomes Benjamin's mentor in the ways of the world.

Menageries of characters pass through `Benjamin's' world. It is they who are rambunctious and animated. They show Benjamin the aspects of life that can easily be missed, and thus bypass the great experiences that life offer. It is Benjamin who realizes that one must be brave enough to grasp these opportunities.

'Benjamin Button' was a movie I had read about, seen the trailers for and was convinced I shouldn't see. I thought I knew pretty much all there was to know already. It wasn't long into the film that I knew I was wrong. With the end credits came the realization that I had just experienced an incredible story.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is one of the BEST movies I've seen in a long time. It's very touching and I recommend it!

After all the hype around this movie, I was really looking forward to suspending reality for a couple of hrs and becoming engrossed in a great story. I was very disappointed in the result. Whilst no doubt a very strong cast in Brad Pitt and Kate Blanchett and a storyline that should transcend to the big screen, something got lost along the way. The film traced the life of a man born old and aging to become young. I found the film too long and for me it 'died' half-way through. That was the point where I stopped caring about Mr. Button, and could very easily have switched off. I perservered and staying to the end and though it did resurrect itself, I had already become bored with it. The film is too long and what should have been great became very average.

This is an overlong, overly dull and a bit too full of itself for it's own good. The story is not interesting, the characters are boring and the plot just never really amounts to much.
I love a great Drama but this is just melodramatic nonsense.

I have to agree with Hollywood that this movie was excellent for scene and costumes. But the story stunk!!

From growing up amongst the elderly who pass away to becoming a baby who doesn't remember or know anyone around him, this movie disappointed me. It was full of death from the very beginning. The father, who never knew his son because he disowned him at birth, was typical.

If you like crying at the end or seeing depressive scenes, this one's for you.

I guess I was expecting a love story. . . NOT SO. Sure, two people fall in love and have a "normal" life for a brief period in time. Not realistic. Not scientific. Not fantasy. Not anything. Certainly not worth seeing in my opinion. I should have saved my money.

G Gupton, author. "The 31-Day Diet of Spiritual Enlightenment" and "Seekers of Truth"
Great film, easy to watch but mesmerizing.  Wonderful actors in the film and the storyline was mind blowing, similar to the book.  A must see film.

Benjamin Button begins life as an old man and ends life as a child. An impossible component but very interesting. However the way they pulled this film off was truly incredible and well deserved all 3 Academy Awards (Best Art Direction, Visual Effects and Makeup). Born as a shriveled infant with eyes blind, joints swollen Benjamin (Brad Pitt) is abandoned on the doorstep of an old-folks home and taken in by Queenie, an African-American woman (a lovely performance by. Slowly, Benjamin takes on the frame of a man well into his '80s.

When Benjamin first meets Daisy (Cate Blanchett), she's perhaps 10 years old to Benjamin's 70, but it's a meeting of children nonetheless. It's also the start of a love story that develops slowly, and eloquently, over the course of decades. The film itself spans the entire course of Benjamin's life, following his "childhood" spent in the home to his "adolescence" spent at sea with Captain Mike, following the currents directly into the events of World War II and home once again, back into the company of Daisy. It's not a complicated film, just a broad one and its magic is simply in the depth of Benjamin's point of view.

This is in large part attributable to the absolute triumph of director David Fincher, whose visual mastery and unsentimental approach never spoon-feeds the audience or over-sweetens the narrative.

The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a magical, heartfelt, joyful and melancholy film, beautiful to look at and filled with wonder. One would be hard-pressed to walk away from the film and not be, somehow, deeply affected by it, a beautiful film.

I heard many good things about this movie when it first came out. I have to say I was very skeptical about it's worth. I finally saw it on DVD. Yes, it was long, but I thought it was beautiful. Fiction of course, but so many of life's lessons were intertwined. In that respect, Forrest Gump did come to mind, but that is it's only similarity. Everybody dreams of growing younger, but being different is very lonely and that is very sad... but so true. I loved it.

For all his good looks and great physique, Brad Pitt has an uncanny ability to pick great movies that explore the human experience and human psyche.  With movies such as Se7en, Jesse James, Babel, Seven Years in Tibet, and now this hit from late 2008, Mr. Pitt has established himself as one of the top actors over the past 2 decades with great performances in multiple genres.  The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is probably Pitt's best work, as he carried the film.  Unlike previous movies, he shares screentime with multiple co-stars in this film such as Tilda Swinton and Cate Blanchett, but carries the movie by himself as his scenes with either of these great actresses alone deserve a Best Actor nod.

This movie is based on a short story of the same name by American literary giant F. S. Fitzgerald.  It tells the story of a Benjamin Button who is born old, and ages young such that his dying breath is that of an infant.  Along the way, he experiences rejection, adultery, war, marriage, fatherhood, longing, family loss and family gained; in short a full and complete life.  The audience sees Mr. Button travel the world as both a poor man and a rich man, from India to Russia to New York to Southeast Asia; all to experience the variety of humanity and the richness of companionship.  Coming in at under 3 hours, this drama is quite riveting.  For a movie with very little action, every minute of the movie held my attention through dialogue that ranged from witty to ironic to insightful; all of which showing that a man need not a college education to express great thoughts.

So all in all, a great movie; surely one of the best of 2008.  My only issue was with the DVD itself; it contained no extra features and did not have an option to choose different scenes.  This is a minus for such a long movie; the ability stop a movie and come back the next day to the scene you left of at is quite important.  Hence the 4 out of 5 stars.

The movie is long but since it is so good, it doesn't feel like that long.  If Forest Gump is 10, this one is a 9.  The story is interesting.  Brad Pitt's acting is just average.  Cate Blanchett is wonderful.  Highly recommended.

The Curious Case of Benjamin Button combines an intriguing story, excellent acting, and first-rate special effects, but, ultimately, it suffers from the weakness of its framing device -- a woman reading her dying mother's journal in New Orleans, just before Hurricane Katrina makes landfall.

The plot is relatively well-known by now:  Benjamin Button (Brad Pitt) is born a wrinkled, arthritic old man who, over time, grows younger as everyone he knows gets older.  Abandoned by his father, Benjamin is raised by  Queenie (Taraji Henson, in a memorable performance), a black servant who takes pity on him, then truly becomes his mother. Benjamin falls in love with Daisy (first Elle Fanning, then Cate Blanchett) and lives an extraordinary varied life, largely through happenstance, much like Forrest Gump.  The frame of the story, with Julia Ormond as Caroline at her dying mother Daisy's bedside, rarely gets mentioned since its effectiveness lags except to drive home the themes of the story:  it's never too late to make something of yourself, that you must grasp the opportunities you have while you can; that life and time are fleeting.  The problem is that the fairy-tale like story of Benjamin Button seems grossly out of place in the midst of a recent current event.  The backdrop of New Orleans and the approaching hurricane seems a forced attempt to get the viewer to embrace this story as true, when instead it detracts from it.

Despite its flaws, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is well worth seeing, if for no other reason than for its unconventional story line and the acting that supports it.  In a time when so many films seem like a rehash of what has been done before, this one offers a refreshing change.
This movie was very disappointing, and too slow - even with the great cast I turned it off halfway -

I'm dissapointed to see David Fincher wasting his time on this melodramatic rubbish. He used to be a director with a message now he's all style and no substance. The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is oscar baiting at it's worst with a concept that runs out of steam in the first thirty minutes and is told quite possibly the worst way; via the Cate Blanchet characters point of view when Benjamin is narrating his own story when we flash back so whats the point of having her in the hospital having her daughter read her a diary? As always with these characters Benajmin is a passive loser surrounded by quirky characters who all pass along a little bit of knowledge about life. This knowledge never rings true and is as shallow as Benjamin himself. He's never angry that he ages backwards. Hell he's barely interested in his own disease you'd never know that he even KNEW he was aging backwards except everyone keeps telling him about it.

The film's lesson is that aging backwards has about as much meaning as aging forward; no meaning at all. Button is a boring and tired protagonist. He's given no obstacles to over come and a girlfriend who treats him like garbage most of the time but he keeps coming back for more just like Forrest Gump and Jenny. For its three hour running time Button has little to say on life but it has alot to say about trying desperately to win an oscar. Shame on you David Fincher for wasting your talents on this dribble.

Whether people remember it as such or not, it feels like Button is the movie that demonstrated when the dust settled on his real life relationship with Angelina Jolie whether the public would enjoy watching him in the movies still.  The answer was a quiet and resounding yes, but this movie still seems to cast a sad note on his career that has an odd feeling of connection to the beginning of his career in "Johnny Suede."

Literature lovers will note the differences in text and the implications of these on this three hour film.  Several added subplots, severe tonal differences from the book and terrible stylistic choices are problems that will sink the hopes of a number of film fans and hoards of casual watchers, but the film's pace is what ultimately makes it unimportant.  For a long, slow, uninvolving, depressed film about a "simple man" it suprises me to be able to say it's also schizophrenic at times, and doesn't really understand the story it's trying to tell.

We think the reason Ben was born this way was because of the blind clockmaker, but that's never truly explained, and confusion with his identity in relation to his age (as opposed to how he looks) seems to be the majority of issue in the film.  It's clear this wasn't what the screenwriter and director wished to express since they don't really make a number of things clear even for those who pay attention. Benjamin Button as a character is impenetrable. You may be able to understand his thinking at times merely because of what's happened in his life and his unique circumstance, but his insight and personal opinion are largely absent which is curious since the story is being told from his own words via his diary and there lies the emotional and character problem with the movie.  The movie isn't really about him and yet he's right there in the center, you'd think he would have more to say.
  His silence on his own feelings is something the audience has to come up with themselves. At first, you think it's because he's a soul trapped and confused but after awhile you suspect and probably settle on the idea that he's mildly retarded because he rarely talks in a way that is more than servicable and writes in a way that tells you everything you don't want to know.  People talk about Forrest Gump comparisons because of the writer and similarities in character, story, and obsession with state of the art effects mimicking old film stock.  Interestingly, Gump says more of his own feelings and perspective even though he seems to be the more mentally hindered of the two.  He also seems to make the most of his oppotunities whereas things just seem to happen to Ben.  I understand the difference in physical infirmities given to Ben, but they can't really justify his lack of action.  In some ways the two characters are the antithesis of one another, one extroverted and natural and the other inward and we really wonder who he is even after the 3 hours.  With such an inward character we grasp out for something to take his place and nothing does.
  We see the affects of his story being read by his daughter to his love on her death bed in what is one of the worst collections of storytelling  ideas in history.  The daughter is underderstandably haggard, why would seeing her invoke anything except a suggestion to take a nap and relax let alone keep flashing back to her telling the story.  While this is happening Hurricane Katrina is about to go off outside and it just reeks of opportunistic fervor in this story.  To top this all off, the elderly woman is Southern and out of breath in an "I'm going to die.....but not just yet, I've got some plot points off ma chest."  Now, I don't want to replicate what she sounds like, but to anyone who's had to experience this kind of speech pattern in real life, southerners included, will no doubt agree that it's the kind of speech that no one wants to listen to since it's pain all around.  Pain for the listener, for the speaker, and for the actor in this instance is in abundance.  Fortunately, it doesn't last very long, but the fact she speaks at all for the rest of the film is terrible.  It comes off as a sick joke at the beginning and only becomes less so because she says less and less until she dies.  Not sure why these two are the two that read the diaries as they're not particularly interesting, or passionate, and come off just as resonant as Ben.
  I made it through the movie well despite it's running time with the help of a Monster energy drink and was very patient and sedate in processing the overlong and basically meaningless film.  Length and pace don't mean a film's boring by themselves, I myself sat through the six hour Italian film "Best of Youth" in succession (the theatre showed them in separate 3 hour increments with separate admission) and was riveted without the aid of any caffiene, vitamin based energy drink, or otherwise.  While the film isn't boring, it also isn't riveting, or thought-provoking due to good storytelling.  Anytime the film causes you to think it's because of details the filmmakers either failed to include, or didn't think were important.

  Examples of this lack of foresight, or ignorance are numerous.  It starts at the beginning with the story of the clock (what's the significance? how does it tie in with the rest of the world?) right down to how mature is Benjamin internally when the world, his mother included, treat him in ways that are probably inappropriate considering his true age.  This is something we're never clued into, but I felt the movie not addressing this was sloppy and not thoughtful.  The fact I'm stating this objection now and not saying "well, who really knows?" is a sign that the movie doesn't really take its central idea seriously they just like what it conjures and that's not good enough.  If you're going to change an original work to fit your meaning it should fit like a glove and their film has a number of ugly tears, misplaced stitches, stains, and frays.  A thoughtful person who doesn't care for storytelling would excuse these problems and say they don't matter, but a person who loves storytelling in all its shapes and sizes will recognize this as substandard work that gets away with it because of the pace, soundtrack, and reserved performances of its leads placing the audience into a dulled silence. There's a reason why it's called the case of Benjamin Button instead of "the story" aside from the literature title, it feels like it's treated as a case and not a story. Fincher is able to make violence tranquill and elegant and boring situations interesting as he does here, but he clearly doesn't have the mind of a writer, or the gift of dramatic detail.
  As for the two stars, I'll let you in on that: it has to do with the tangental elements the film doesn't really use.  The story of the clockmaker although told through the voice of old dying woman is still more interesting than a majority of the story and his heartfelt apology to the people after he explains why it ticks backward is truly moving.  The man who was struck by lightning seven times conversely is kind of silly but it lightens up a murky mood and distracts from the lack of momentum the movie feels throughout.  Finally, the character who merges both of these strengths is tugboat captain played by Jared Harris.  He's always good and sometimes feels out of place because of his strong acting choices and accent, but he's always bringing vigor and vitality to his roles.  Here, he makes you completely forget everything that happened before he stepped into frame and he makes you sad that he's leaving after being wounded in the submarine incident.  He's an artist indeed and the only one who emerges victorius in his battle with the drab and lukewarm plot.
  I don't recommend this film to anyone because it has nothing going for it. The good spots are enough to outweigh the bland and empty and it wastes a lot of talent.  Even Brad Pitt fans won't get what they want.  There are love scenes and sex is a major issue that comes up in the course of his life, however, it's treated in a very limited manner and even the emotional payoffs are shortchanged.  In short, nothing is savored and there's no sex to make it titilatting.  I would hesitate, in fairness, before admitting it's not even sensual which actually accurately describes the whole movie.  It's not a sense of taste, or attention span, that seals the deal, but a lack of story and plot instead of heart.  A Curious Case indeed.
We found the movie to be most excellent. All aspects of the movie were very well done.

This is Fincher in his Spielberg, circa "Amazing Stories" mode. I really find this to be "minor" Fincher, more accomplished than Alien3 but less vital than anything else he's made thus far, it felt like a "kid in a candy store" production.

Having said that, I could watch Cate Blanchet all day and she is positively glowing in this film -- albeit digitally enhanced. Brad is Brad, the acting is not groundbreaking. The making of is very well made and after see it, I couldn't help but think what that the scrapped Spielberg or Spike Jonze versions might be superior.

Fincher tone seems strangely distant, unable/unwilling to peer into the soul of Benjamin, as a mainstream film, it is accessible and entertaining, but for a Fincherfilm(tm), I felt let down after the epic that was Zodiac.

Veteran Film Critic Pauline Cael once said film art is defined by how little pretence and self-congratulatory ruminations can be found within a film. The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is such a film. There are many more films than this with a far more believable premise that do not stand up to scrutiny the way this masterpiece does.  The ;ast film (and only
film until this one) that actually made me produce tears was Philip Noyce's brilliant remake of The Quiet American, a masterpiece along with
this gem. There are many excellent films that I soon forget after watching, but Brad Pitt's performance carried a chivalry, presence and nuance that was simply amazing to behold. This film is beatiful in its
sadness and ennui and will in ten-year's time stand up to scrutiny
as a masterpiece of filmmaking.  David Fincher, some of us may have laughed at you when you made "SEVEN" years ago, we are laughing no longer.

I wasn't sure what to expect so I downloaded on to my itouch instead of spending the money ( due to the economy )...I knew it got very mixed reviews. I knew that Fitzgerald wrote it as a short story and that Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett were the playing the leads( loved "Interview with a Vampire"  and " Elizabeth " )and it was set in New Orleans. It was the reviews that got to me...most so different, so I had to see for myself. After almost 3 hours of watchng it I fell in love with the characters and all the changes throughout the many decades that Benjamin & Daisy went through, together and apart. From the end of WWI 1918 to 2006 an entire life span. It was an epic film... as in forrest Gump epic where you were living the history with them and saw the times changing. No matter what age Benjamin was at the time, they loved each other, But he had the wisdom to know he had to wait for Daisy to grow up emotionally, before she was ready to fall in love with him.( they had to meet in the middle ) I could feel the emotion  just by watching the film ( which is harder to portray in films and easier to do in books ...it's usually the other way around )No matter where they were in the world, they always found each other. The ending was predictable you knew it was coming, but still needed to watch it to the end. I probably would have given it 5 stars, but it was sooooooooo long, happy I watched at home so I could get comfortable and could pause the movie  when needed. Long after the movie I'm still thinking about Benjamin & Daisy which means the movie is still growing on me, which leads me to believe that I will be purchasing it. If you have the time, put the movie in the DVD and clear the evening to enjoy it.

This is, while a technically brilliant piece of filmmaking that fully exploits all the wizardry of CGI and makeup of which the filmmaker's art is now capable, strangely hollow at the center.  One begins the movie expecting some profound truths about human existence to be explored, but it ends not with a big life-affirming bang, but more of a whimper, quite literally.  Benjamin says though his diary at one point: "Life is defined by opportunities--even the ones we miss."  And that could be a sum-up of this film project as a whole, as well as the life of the bizarre hero at its center.  One gets the sense of promise grasped for here but not quite realized as the technical and stylistic gymnastics of this movie overwhelm the fragile love story that should be its beating heart.

The film opens with Mr. Gateau (Cake) constructing a magical clock that runs backwards and mounting it in a train station in New Orleans in honor of his son, dead in the Great War.  No mention is made again of Mr. Gateau or whether his clock was successful in rewinding time to bring dead boys back to life.  It does have a curious effect on the life of one boy, though, as Benjamin enters the world essentially running backwards.  As other reviewers have pointed out, it's quizzical that the clock has this metaphysical effect on only Benjamin among all the other children born afterwards, but then, fantasy is not required to operate by the rules of logic. Perhaps Benjamin, with a Gullah mother was particularly susceptible to magic, and how serendipitous that old-man baby Benjamin's grieving father abandoned him, along with $18 on the steps of an old-folks home, rather than say, a brothel . . .this being New Orleans, after all.  What are the chances, outside the realm of fantastical fiction, furthermore that Benjamin's progenitor be named Mr. Button, and that he own a button factory?  Otherwise we wouldn't have such nifty alliteration.

Countless comparisons have been made to "Forrest Gump", with which this narrative does share structural similarities.  However, that didn't occur to me while I was watching and found instead resonance with one of Pitt's earlier characters, Tristan Ludlow from "Legends of the Fall"--like Benjamin, Tristan is a soul set apart, blessed or cursed with mystical powers he does not fully understand; uncomfortable among other people and destined to lose the true love of his life due to his own inability to live a normal life.  Scenes of Benjamin travelling to foreign shores and sailing a boat underscored this impression.  (The presence of Julia Ormond, here playing the adult daughter of the aged Daisy was just a bonus, since she and Pitt have no scenes together.)  The setting of New Orleans during Benjamin's childhood in the early decades of the last century also reminded me of Louis Malle's "Pretty Baby".

This film is technically dazzling, but I think it was justly deprived of the top acting awards.  With so much else to be distracted by, the acting had a job of it to even be noticed, really.  Cate Blanchett is luminous, as usual.  I had my doubts a 38-year-old mother of three could pull off a 23-year-old ballerina, but La Blanchett can do anything.  The greatest curiosity I had, to be honest, was in how they were going to make Brad Pitt look 18 again.  Brad has taken pretty good care of his body over the years, but the strain of being father to the United Tribe of Benetton is starting to show . . .at least when he's not on a movie set.  When he's lit and coiffed for a film, he does not look anything like a 46-year-old father of six.  He can easily pass for a decade younger . . .but I thought 18 would be pushing it.  Well . . . did I say that the makeup department is amazing??  Looking at the scene of an 18-year-old Benjamin coming to visit the now-58-year-old Daisy--wow.  It was like having a flashback to Mr. Pitt's debut in "Thelma & Louise", and it was a very unsettling feeling.  "Unsettling" is the best descriptor for this movie.  Parts of it were stunning to look at, but its tragic meditations on the ultimate inablity of love to bring any meaning to human life leaves you wrung out and uncertain whether you are better off having seen it than you were before.

This movies is the biggest waste of time that I have ever seen.  I debated paying someone to take this movie after I was done watching it instead I just threw it in the trash.  For one thing, half of the stupid movie is done in flasback black and white.  Plus, it is so easy for people to get lost in this movie.  Of the two people watching it with me, I was the only one who could keep up with the storyline.  This movie had elements that really just ticked me off.  First of all if you are pentecostal, it makes us look like nuts who shove people over and thank God for a miracle that really did not happen.  It uses curse words for emphasis in places where emphasis is not needed.  Then within the last thirty minutes of the movie, it feels that it can redeem itself by throwing in partial sex scene after partial sex scene.  It also throws in some lesbian comments that were just so out of place.  I honesly believe that they should use this movie for torture at Guantonomo Bay.  If you can watch this movie and not crack, then you are extremely tough.  What a waste of time.  And like another review said, it tries to mix so many movies.  I see elements of the Titanic, Forrest Gump, Terminator, etc.  This movie is so ridiculous.
Fantastic movie! Best I've seen in years! Wonderfully involving and gives you a lot to think about afterwards.

This is not normally my type of movie. Moreover, Brad Pitt is not always my favorite actor. Yet he knows how to pick movies with a character that is made just for him. This movie definitely is. The basic premise is simple. It is of a person, Benjamin button, whom was born old and becomes younger with time. We get to follow his life through a series of flashbacks in which the reader eventually realizes she is his daughter. The story line is simple but what makes the movie is the presentation from the color the sound to the great acting. This is one of those movies that doesn't take you very long to forget that you're watching a movie and it makes you feel like you're part. Be sure to watch the movie again with the voiceover by David Fincher and you will see what he is trying to portray and how well he does it. The cinema presentation is loosely based on a story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. I have only seen the Blu-Ray Criterion version of this film so I cannot comment on the others. Meet Joe Black Teknolust~ Tilda Swinton
It is a great movie, and it also has some deep meanings, if you listen carefully to the dialogs.

Though The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is long (we watched half of it one night, the other half on another night), I think it's rich with fantasy, amazing production qualities (the film is gorgeous to look at, from start to finish), and some really good performances.

The plot: Benjamin Button (played by Brad Pitt) is born at the end of World War I to a wealthy New Orleans family. His mother dies in childbirth. When Benjamin's father sees his new son, he is horrified. The baby appears unnaturally aged/sick, with wrinkled skin. The shocked, unprepared new father leaves the infant on a doorstep.

Luckily, that doorstep belongs to an old folks' home managed by Queenie (Taraji P. Henson, in an inspired performance). Heartsick Queenie is unable to have children of her own, and she takes the unfortunate little one in. As a child, Benjamin has the appearance and physical ability of a 70-year-old man and the mental capabilities of a child. The older Benjamin gets, however, the more apparent it becomes - he's aging backwards.

It's at the home that Benjamin meets Daisy (Cate Blanchett). The two feel an instant connection.

As Benjamin hits his teenaged years, he takes a job on a tugboat, travels the world, and begins to live his life. The rest of the movie follows he and Daisy (who grows up to be a prima ballerina) as the two find love, find one another, and experience the inevitable loss that is characteristic of the human experience.

Cast-wise, I think the star is clearly Blanchett, followed at a close second by Henson. Though Pitt does an admirable job, his Benjamin is a man of few words, which doesn't do much for the acting fireworks.

Effects/makeup were wonderful, though I did feel that dim lighting in many scenes affected my full appreciation of the technology used to both age characters and "turn back the clock." (It was almost as if they were trying to hide Pitt in some scenes, maybe for a bigger reveal later? At any rate, I didn't like it. Just tell the story.)

There was alot of symbolism in this movie, a lot of imagery related to time/mortality throughout the film, and many themes dealing with "other" types. If you're thinking that the film will bear any resemblance to the F. Scott Fitzgerald story it's based on, think again. The movie uses the basic premise of the story, nothing more.

I was -like many other people- willing to like this movie, but it manages to disappoint consistently for all but its last 15 minutes.

The cosmic reasons for Benjamin's backward aging are never explained (the clock at the train station is NOT an explanation - since one would rationally assume that several babies would have been born that same night in the city with the same condition as he). It is nothing more than a gimmick since neither existential issues nor insights are drawn from his surprisingly uninteresting life. The writing doesn't help much since when it tries to be deep or insightful that's precisely the impression it gives; that it is trying.

The main acting talent in this movie is absolutly top-notch. Pitt delivers consistently and this movie was no exception. Taraji Henson is truthful (if a little restrained) and Cate Blanchett is without a doubt one of the best film actors of her generation. Yet, it is the vague movie direction by David Fincher (who was great in Zodiac) which wastes the talent in what could have been an epic movie.

Characters move through the movie without clear motivations or objectives and often seem not to be affected by what happens to them. Button's obstinacy in loving Daisy should be the backbone of the movie, but when faced by the prospect of being a father while growing younger he leaves without considering alternatives, and Daisy doesn't even put up much of a fight! Parents would do anything to avoid their child's suffering, but why did Benjamin never consider that due to his own extraordinary circumstances, his child would just have to live an unusual life? Wouldn't his child be better served by having a mature parent for at least 11 years of her life than not having him at all? How many parents who die prematurely would not give anything to spend a little more time with their kids? These are not easy questions to answer but the movie doesn't bother to ask them, either.

The movie spends a good amount of celluloid telling a story in the longest, most roundabout way possible. At first, still giving it a chance I focused more on the atmosphere being created, but there wasn't much there either. Benjamin joins a ship, has an affair and faces one battle in WWII and doesn't seemed changed by any of it, because he apparently thinks his life is less interesting than even we do. When he comes back home, the level of his joy at seeing Queenie (his "mom") would tell one he's been gone only a week and not a few years... at war! I blame this not on Pitt's or Henson's acting but on Fincher's direction. While one could make the concession that living in a home where people constantly died made Benjamin less willing to become attached to anyone, that would also mean that it makes the character less interesting, since apathy is not a quality one wishes to see in a main character.

To boot, while the story of his life is being pieced together by diary entries (thus obviously from a first person perspective) when narrating how Daisy's accident came to end her dancing career; Benjamin momentarily develops an omniscient narrative; he knows every single detail of what led to it (one is left wondering why he didn't use that omniscience in preventing an eventual pregnancy that he apparently never wanted to happen). The narrative itself is interesting but it violates the premise the movie had already established.

The bad choices made in this film are many but the final fifteen minutes almost make one say it makes up for them. The final scene of Benjamin's life, when Daisy narrates his final moments and the absolutly loving, heartbreaking way in which she covers the face of the dead baby Benjamin in her arms, is the most beautiful scene I have seen in any movie. She was being a mother to the man who once was her husband and Blancett nailed every single gesture and emotion when taking care of young Benjamin. Blanchett is amazing.

The movie goes on to tie Daisy's own passing to the Katrina disaster, which also destroys the clock (which never stopped running and is now relegated to a basement). A montage follows in which the people who touched Benjamin's life are seen doing what they did, but it doesn't seem to mean much and the viewer is thrown back into vagueness. One is left wondering, after almost three hours of watching, what was it exactly that The Curious Case of Benjamin Button wanted to say.

Visually, this is one of the most beautiful films I have ever seen.  Every period in the film, from the roaring '20s of Benjamin's earliest years, to the 1960s when he lived briefly with the girl of his dreams, are captured almost perfectly onscreen.  The cinematography is practically flawless.  The film is so wonderfully atmospheric it's almost worth watching for that alone.  The special effects are remarkable as well.  At different points in the film, both Cate Blanchett and Brad Pitt are made to look roughly twenty years younger than their actual ages.  This is relatively new in film.  It's been possible since the medium began to age actors with makeup, but now it's also possible to de-age them through the magic of CGI.  So where it would once have only been possible to make this film using very young actors to play the leads, and use make up to age them into their 40s and 50s and beyond, they can now cast established stars in their 40s and still have them convincingly play characters just out of their teens.  The technical wizardry behind this is amazing, and it's yet another example of the magic of the movies.

So on technical merits alone I'd give the film 5 out of 5 stars.  Unfortunately, the story does not quite live up to that high standard.  It's not bad, to be sure; I did enjoy the movie, but I couldn't help wonder, at the end of it all, what the point was.  As the reviewer for the Sunday Times aptly put it: "It's a gimmick that goes on for nearly three hours."  Now I don't think every story has to have a moral, or a great message, or all kinds of weighty allusions and themes, and so forth.  But simple, escapist entertainment just works better as a comedy or an action piece.  A moody, character-driven drama, one can't help but feel, ought to have a little more to say.  This movie, enjoyable as it is, seems like nothing more than an exercise in "what if" thinking -- what if a man could age backward?  What would that be like?  Storywise, the film seems to have nothing to offer beyond that, and one really doesn't need a 2 1/2 hour film to spell out all the sorrowful ramifications of such a scenario.

Still, the film is good for an evening's entertainment, and is a feast for the eyes.  Cate Blanchett is nearly always worth watching, and Pitt gives a very good performance as well.

I saw the movie at the theater.  I could not wait until it came out on DVD to rent. As soon I saw it again, I had to purchase it from Amazon to get the additional behind the scenes disk.  Wow! Amazon made it happen
for me.  All my friends want to borrow the two disks. Amazon, you rock!
Amazon has been my resource for other music albums and wireless headphones.

Mix several parts "Titanic" with "Forrest Gump" and "The Jerk"; fold in elements of "Back to the Future" along with the atmosphere and diction from a Tennessee Williams play. Stir at length until mixture becomes stiff and heavy before baking for two hours and forty-six minutes, preferably while a CAT 5 hurricane is bearing down on you.

I didn't recognize anything remotely reminiscent of F. Scott Fitzgerald in the result; but if this formula sounds appealing to you, you'll love "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button".

I can honestly say that I saw this movie 3 times in the theater and countless times on DVD. This is one of those movies that are made every once in a while like Forrest Gump, The Green Mile or My Life. They don't make movies of this caliber in Hollywood anymore.

I was shocked to say the least when I realized that Brad Pitt was to play a role like this. But the same I could say about Tom Hanks when he did Forrest after a vast array of comedies he did before that.

There are some similarities between this movie and Forrest but they are completely different stories. It also so happens that the screenwriter was the same one - ERIC ROTH.

I was quite dissapointed at the Oscars as I thought this movie was going to clean out and only got 3 awards and the rest was given to Slumdog Millionaire and Sean Penn got the best actor. I guess they were being sympathetic to the gay community because Brad Pitt really did a hell of a job and did deserved the best actor at the oscars this year.

 But at least there are people like me that are here to tell you the how grand this movie really is and is worth every penny that you spend on it.

RATING 10

RAY GAYO 007

Before I say anything, I think David Fincher is, not ONE OF, but THE best modern day director around. Unlike most directors of today, he is meticulous and strives for perfection. His images are perfect. His pre-planning and attention to detail is rivaled by only a few, including Alfred Hitchcock. While some film makers are caught up in the money pool and rush to the cinema, Fincher takes his time, chooses his projects carefully and makes darn sure that everything he does is perfect and without flaw.

Everything above applies to THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTONS with one very important exception, at least in this reviewer's opinion. The movie is flawed in one very important way. The pacing is absolutely awful. It is a slow-moving, one-note movie that starts you off with a creative idea about a baby born with the skin of an elderly man. Then the baby becomes a short, frail, wheel-chair old man that begins to age, backward. Once that is established, the movie allows you to watch Benjamin Buttons (Brad Pitt) life unfold.

Twice I sat down to watch it, and twice I lost interest. Eventually I decided to fast forward through the beginning part that I had already seen twice, and attempt to finish it. I figured I owed it to my favorite director.

Everything about BENJAMIN BUTTONS, other than pacing is perfection, just as I stated before. Fincher is a master at his craft. Brad Pitt, Cate Blanchett and Taraji Henson are exceptional. The movie as a whole is a concept movie that tried to be made into a trophy winner. What it needed was somebody to realize, that it's just a movie and it needed to be trimmed and rethunk.
this is a great movie and even better quality blu ray..the picture quality is the best that ive seen yet...i highly recomend it to anyone..
I saw the show it was terrific so i got the DVD. Brad pit was great.
....Since Brad Pitt starred in Meet Joe Black, I make it a point of following his movies. This movie is a great showing of his acting ability. This movie is science fiction..just remember that.

Lotsa folks' reviews compare this interminable movie--filmed with state of the art effects about a strange simple southern man uttering nuggets of wisdom as he moves episodically through peace time and war time, on land and sea, befriended by eccentric characters, all the while in love with a childhood friend who comes in and out of his life--with ANOTHER interminable movie filmed with state of the art effects about a strange simple southern man, etc.... Could that be because "Button" screenwriter Eric Roth is also the guy who wrote "Forrest Gump"?

Cate Blanchett, quit telling your stupid story about the stupid old guy and just die already!

I wasn't prepared for how lousy this film was, despite the fact that it looked pretty and the stars did a reasonably good job. Dull, plodding, slow, awful screenplay full of cheap platitudes trying to pass as wisdom, ugh. Close to three hours I'll never get back in my life. Made me wish I could have gone backwards and skipped this. I really expected better from David Fincher and from the critics who placed this on their lists of best of the year.

I had not seen this movie in the theatre but had many people comment on it both positive and negative. I decided that I wanted to see it for myself. I am glad that I did. I liked parts of the movie and others I didn't but it was such an unusual movie it was certainly worth the time to see.

This is one of the best movies I've watched all year, a story so far removed from the norm, you won't want to take your eyes off the screen for a second.  Watching, you'll wonder whether or not the romance between Benji and Daisy will lead to them spending their lives together, but the story is so much more than a romance.  It's a tale of family, love, and life, of taking what life has to offer and living to the fullest.

Don't miss this movie!
